SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Last Thursday, 10 October, I made a brief statement to the Senate in respect of certain shares I held jointly with my wife in several Australian public companies. I must now inform the Senate that I have inadvertently misled the chamber. In response to Senator Sherry's motion concerning potential conflicts of interest I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure the Senate that I have had no conflict of interest during the last six months, nor do I expect one to occur.

At the time I made this statement I believed it to be true. However, since Thursday my staff and the Department of the Treasury have been double‐checking all the administrative matters that have been processed through my office in the past seven months. As you would appreciate, Madam President, there has been a very large number of matters.

Yesterday, my staff discovered a minor administrative action that I processed in late June, which I must now bring to the attention of the Senate. I would like to take a moment to explain what the matter was.

The Australian Securities Commission had received an application from a company, Boral Energy (Vic) Pty Ltd, seeking a declaration that it could be included in the Victorian electricity exempt futures market which had been created by the former Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch, in May last year.

An exempt futures market status is intended for specialist futures markets which are for professional, specialist investors only. Applications to the Australian Securities Commission are assessed against criteria set out in its policy statement No. 70. As I said, the Victorian electricity exempt futures market was created in May 1995 when 12 electricity companies were declared exempt by the then Attorney‐General. On 27 September last year, two more participants were included in that list.

In a memorandum dated 25 June this year, Treasury recommended that I approve a recommendation from the ASC that Boral Energy (Vic) Pty Ltd be declared exempt; that is, that the company be allowed to participate in the Victorian electricity exempt futures market.

The futures market is about participants hedging their risks. All participants in this exempt market are professional energy companies. The Victorian market is a precursor to the establishment of a national electricity market, which is expected to become operative next year. I accepted the Treasury's and the ASC's advice and signed the declaration on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Costello).

As the Senate is aware, in June this year I held shares in Boral Ltd. The particular company, Boral Energy (Vic) Pty Ltd, is a related company to Boral. Six months earlier, my wife and I sold a significant volume of shares we held, including a number of Boral shares, for the purpose of financing an investment property. The details of those sales were included in my notification to the Registrar of Senators' Interests on 19 January this year.

Unfortunately, when the memorandum was placed in front of me for consideration, my memory was that my wife and I had sold all our Boral shares; and I acted on that basis. I was wrong to do so. I should not have signed the declaration and I should have passed it to the Treasurer for action.

It is of little comfort to say that I regret my action. My failure to act on this matter, in accordance with accepted procedure, was not a deliberate attempt to advance my private interests. Indeed, there can be no question of putting private interests before public duty as, in this case, my duty was to grant Boral Energy the relevant declaration. By doing so, competition in the market for electricity was increased. The decision was one recommended to me by both the market regulator, the ASC, and the policy department, the Treasury. I accepted that advice and acted accordingly.

Nevertheless, I consider integrity to be of the utmost importance and the course of action I should follow has been quite clear. While there was no intended impropriety on my part, it is clear to me that these circumstances could be perceived to constitute a conflict of interest and my failure to act accordingly necessitates the action I have taken.

My error was found only yesterday and I notified the Treasurer immediately. Further checks were undertaken to confirm my mistake. Once those processes had been properly completed, I took the only honourable action possible. I now wish to inform the Senate that, with the greatest regret, yesterday evening I tendered to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) my resignation as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer. This morning, the Prime Minister informed me that he had accepted my resignation.

Madam President, I have always declared my private interests to the Senate. Unlike many other employees, my superannuation from past employment was largely in shares. These shares were held jointly with my wife and were purchased long before I came to this place. They were always intended to provide income for us during retirement.

While my circumstances will be judged by others in the days ahead, and I stand ready to accept the inevitable criticism of my actions that will undoubtedly follow, I would hope that my example will demonstrate the need in Australia for the establishment of a system of blind trusts to support executive officers of government, statutory officer holders, members of the judiciary and others. A blind trust places an individual's assets at arm's length while they hold public office.

I would like to take the opportunity to thank the people who have helped me in the last seven months. I thank my staff, the departmental people from the business law division of Treasury, who have been excellent to me, and the ASC and its commissioners. I particularly thank the Treasurer and the Prime Minister for their assistance and help. Australia is in good hands. I commend their actions. I commend them for their assistance and their trust in me for the past seven months. I inadvertently misled the Senate and I extend my unreserved apologies to senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't salivate quite so much; it is unbecoming.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that every now and then attempts are being made by those on the other side to drive some sort of wedge between me and Senator Hill. —Don't say `rubbish' to me. You were looking at amendments yourself.

ANSWER.PARA: Ministers are not precluded from making investments on the stock markets or other financial and trading markets . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question is directed to Senator Hill. How does the following statement, Minister, made by Mr Moore in the Age newspaper on 29 May 1996 sit with the Prime Minister's guidelines? I quote:

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. Again, I am afraid that Senator Faulkner just fails to appreciate what is being said. Ministers should be able to maintain contacts. They must be able to maintain contacts.
—Despite conflict of interest?
—You fail to understand the point.
—Are you rewriting the rules already?

—The rules provide that you can maintain investments. There is no question about that. They say that you cannot trade. We dealt with that issue in the first part of the question. The supplementary is: are ministers prohibited from having any contact with those in business out of a fear that the person that they are speaking with could have some other interest? No, they are not prohibited. It would be ridiculous. You are trying to head down the same path as Senator Kernot, in many ways, by creating these artificial situations that make it impossible for people to exist.

—My question without notice is directed to Senator Alston as the Minister for Communications and the Arts. The minister would be aware that concerns have been expressed in the community about the effect on health of electromagnetic radiation from household devices like mobile phones and in television and radio broadcasts. Has the government investigated these concerns? If so, what are the findings of those investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue and it is one that we have been addressing now for some months. I am pleased to announce today that the government has decided to implement a research and information program to address community concerns about exposure to electromagnetic energy occurring in the radiofrequency range of the spectrum. This includes exposure to mobile phones, mobile phone towers and broadcast towers.

ANSWER.PARA: The program will consist of a public information dissemination strategy, continuing participation in the World Health Organisation's project to assess the health and environmental effects of EME exposure, and an independent Australian research program. The government will allocate $4.5 million over five years to fund this program. The cost of the program will be fully offset by a small increase in radiocommunications licence fees to commence in November 1996. The government has been developing this radiofrequency electromagnetic energy program for some months. We have taken into account community representations and the results of an independent community awareness survey, which was conducted by AGB McNair on the basis of a consultancy awarded by the Department of Communications and the Arts on 19 July last. We have also taken account of the recommendations of the Senate majority report on the proposed sale of part of Telstra, together with international developments and other pertinent issues.

I am advised that the weight of national and international scientific opinion is that there is no substantive evidence of adverse health and safety effects from radiofrequency emissions at typical levels. Australian exposure standards reflect the current state of knowledge and are as stringent as any national standards in operation internationally.

There is still a need, however, for further research and to provide information to the public. The rapid development of communications technology and improved scientific research and interpretation techniques ensure that there are always issues warranting further investigation. The government's commitment to the RF EME program therefore ensures that the health and safety of Australian citizens and residents are not compromised by developments in communications. The government's program represents a measured and sensible approach designed to ensure that Australians continue to enjoy the benefits of new communications technology and infrastructure, while addressing any public concerns about possible health effects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, either the Labor people are slow learners or some organ grinder has cranked out a series of questions on the other side and, irrespective of the answers given to previous questions, they just go along and parrot the next question. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. I note and welcome your comments in response to the question relating to the possible health effects of electromagnetic radiation. Will the government insist that no further mobile phone towers are erected in close proximity to schools, kindergartens and hospitals until the completion of that review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Implicit in the question is a presumption of guilt. The very purpose of having an inquiry is to ascertain whether there are any grounds for additional concerns. The fact is that there is no evidence to date to suggest that people are at risk. There are standards with which we comply very significantly. In other words, we act conservatively by international standards.

PARA.BREAK: The proposition that somehow you ought to suddenly assume that there is a radiation danger and that people are suffering ahead of the inquiry seems to me to be absolute non sense. There is a national code designed to regulate the location of mobile phone towers and other transmission facilities. They take account of existing health concerns. But, at the end of day, the purpose of the inquiry is to allay, as much as possible, the concerns that you and others have been implying but not providing any evidence to support.

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the inquiry is to assure the public that, as much as possible, we can have an independent assessment of the level of electromagnetic energy emitted by radio frequency transmissions so that they can have confidence in a scientific assessment rather than having to respond to those who might be out there wanting to simply presume the worst and create fears and concerns that are not substantiated by evidence.

It is from an abundance of caution that we have taken this action. We think it will go a long way towards alleviating a lot of community concern, which we believe is unnecessary, on the current state of the evidence. To the extent that there are continuing changes in technology and continuing developments in scientific research, we think it is prudent to ensure that those matters are taken into account.

This is an international issue. The World Health Organisation has been pursuing it for a long time. We are involved directly in those issues. I think we have an interdepartmental committee that has been examining the issues for some months. It is arising out of their recommendations that we commissioned that research back in July of this year. In other words, the government has been well and truly aware that there are people who will continue to suggest that there might be problems even though there is no evidence to support that. On that basis, we thought it was about time that we ensured that a scientific assessment was made that was independent of the players who might be involved in the construction of towers and other facilities. This will ensure that people have the maximum degree of confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response. Is it not prudent for the government to adopt the precautionary principle in this respect? ANSWER.PARA: It is against that background that we are nonetheless putting in train an inquiry and funding it with substantial sums of money. To go beyond that and talk about giving guarantees and being prepared to pay compensation ahead of the verdict simply means that you are not really interested in having an open mind on the issue. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —This mess is entirely the making of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The guidelines that were laid down in this document will be complied with in full.

The nature of the ministerial guide—

The Prime Minister said:
I repeat that the ministerial guide places an obligation on ministers to comply.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations

PARA.EMPHASIS: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
(1) The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

(2) The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

(3) The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
(4) Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
(5) The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
(6) The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
(7) The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

(8) The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with over‐award gender based pay equity issues.
(9) A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
(10) Workers under State industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

I am pleased to table this report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on the abolition of the development import finance facility, or DIFF scheme. DIFF was introduced into the Australian aid program by the Fraser coalition government in 1982. It combined grant funds and export credits to provide concessional loans for developing countries to finance high priority public sector development projects. The present government decided on 8 May this year to terminate the scheme from 1 July.

As a result of continuing refinements to the scheme within Australia and stricter OECD guidelines for mixed credits, DIFF in 1996 bore little resemblance to the original scheme. DIFF was a development scheme with broad humanitarian objectives. By any definition, the overwhelming majority of DIFF projects approved since the inception of the OECD's 1992 Helsinki rules could be classed as humanitarian aid. Many projects had a significant impact at local community level: for example, in education, renewable energy and environmental areas. It was, in fact, a very successful scheme.

An important secondary benefit of DIFF was that it enabled Australian companies to compete on an equal footing with foreign companies when vying for development projects. DIFF was not a subsidy to Australian business but extended to recipient countries terms which enabled them to consider Australian bids for development projects. Recently about 85 per cent of projects funded under the scheme were nominated by recipient countries and not by commercial interests. Projects reflected primarily the development priorities of those countries.

When the Australian government terminated DIFF, it decided not to proceed any further with 50 projects which had received a letter of advice but had not received a letter of formal offer. These projects had received formal notification from AusAID that they were of sufficient priority and met the general eligibility requirements but had still to pass certain formal appraisal processes. The overwhelming evidence presented to the committee suggested that companies and recipient governments regarded the letter of advice as indicating that, subject to a satisfactory completion of those appraisal processes, DIFF funding would be forthcoming. AusAID has assured the committee that, as DIFF operated, 70 per cent of projects with a letter of advice proceeded to completion.

The committee believes that the decision not to proceed with these projects represents the narrowest possible legalistic approach to the termination of DIFF. It took no account of Asian business culture based upon development of relationships, trust and commitments. It ignored the pleas of senior ministers of recipient countries not to scrap particular projects. It took no account of considerable investments made by recipient countries, sometimes at the direct request of the Australian government. And it dealt a serious blow to relations, particularly commercial relations, between Australia and regional countries.

The termination of DIFF has had an adverse impact not only on the communities affected but also on Australia's standing as a provider of humanitarian relief to developing countries. The committee noted that the government has acknowledged the continuing need for concessional finance to support the massive infrastructure needs of developing countries in the region, citing a figure of $US1.5 trillion for infrastructure needs in South‐East and East Asia in the next decade.

In the next five years alone developing countries in the region will require $US8.5 billion for pollution and emission controls and $US7 billion for water and sanitation each year. These are the very areas on which DIFF projects were concentrating. The committee finds the government's decision to terminate not only the DIFF scheme itself but also specific projects in the pipeline to be inexplicable and inconsistent with its own rhetoric.

The decision has had a severe impact on many Australian companies, which have lost projects worth $1.3 billion. The short‐sighted nature of the decision to terminate DIFF can be seen in the fact that one New South Wales company alone will lose $110 million of export earnings in order to help the government save $70 million this year by terminating DIFF. The government has created an export `black hole'.

Although a few big name players appear on the list of Australian companies involved in DIFF, most companies involved were small to medium sized enterprises—many of these subcontracted to 50 or more other companies. They will now no longer be able to employ additional staff as anticipated. Some will have to lay off staff. Many companies had invested large sums in particular projects, and considerable time and resources. These investments have now been lost.

Vying for a DIFF contract entailed commercial risk. There was often strong competition from other Australian and overseas companies. Companies also had to meet all AusAID's DIFF requirements and to subject their proposals to OECD scrutiny. These risks were accepted as normal commercial risks. What cannot be construed in any possible way as commercial risk was the government's arbitrary decision to terminate DIFF. DIFF was the basis on which all of the projects were negotiated and implemented. Without DIFF, Australian companies could not even get to the negotiating table.

DIFF enabled Australian companies to win follow‐on business in important developing markets. Even discounting the automatic multiplier provided by the combination of grant and loan funds in DIFF projects, the accepted figure was $2.30 of further business for Australian companies generated by every dollar of DIFF funding. In many cases DIFF was instrumental in establishing a market presence and earning credibility for a company which was then able to win further, fully commercial contracts. These opportunities will now be lost.

For a government which trumpets its concern for small business, which assures us of its interest in engaging with Asia and which makes much of its desire to increase employment, the decision is monumentally ill‐judged. The committee therefore recommends that all projects holding letters of advice should be processed in the normal way and that funds be made available to AusAID to finance projects which successfully pass the appraisal processes.

The government has indicated that it will consider introducing a revised mixed credits scheme as early as 1997‐98. It is included in the terms of reference of the Simons review of Australia's aid program. The committee believes that a revised scheme as outlined in the department of foreign affairs and AusAID submission largely describes DIFF, either as it was or at least as it was evolving.

If the government were to suspend DIFF for only one year, it is incomprehensible why the government did not simply revise it instead of going through the trauma of terminating it and then replacing it with a similar scheme, incurring substantial damage to the national interest in the process.

The committee believes that DIFF was an effective element in Australia's overall aid program. It also provided significant benefits for Australian companies, particularly in the sector providing high technology capital goods, arguably the most important sector for Australia's future trade performance. The committee therefore recommends that the Australian government not wait for the financial year 1997‐98 but introduce, at the earliest possible time, another mixed credits scheme to replace DIFF. The committee also recommends that, given the significant environmental needs in the region—acknowledged by the government—the percentage of projects under the green DIFF component in any new mixed credit scheme be raised to 40 per cent.

Many witnesses who appeared before the committee spoke of the importance of personal relationships and trust established over a long period of time in business dealings in Asian countries, and of the enormous damage done to commercial relationships by the decision to terminate DIFF. The withdrawal of Australian government support for these projects is regarded as a serious breach of faith on the part of Australia.

At first, Mr Downer tried to play down the strength of the criticisms of regional countries. In answer to a question without notice on 18 June in the House of Representatives, he replied that `not one minister' has raised concerns with him. One by one, the written and oral criticisms of ministers of regional countries were made public. The minister was forced to apologise for misleading Parliament.

The strength of the adverse reaction in the region to the original decision to terminate DIFF is evident in the minister's decision on 22 July to provide funding for some high priority projects nominated by recipient governments. The committee believes that this embarrassing partial policy reversal only serves to emphasise the precipitate and ill‐considered nature of the original decision. Moreover, this about‐turn has also heightened the confusion in the region about Australia's intentions and can only further erode Australia's credibility as a reliable aid provider and neighbour.

During examination of these matters in the public hearings, the committee sought certain documents and information which officers of the department and AusAID referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer). The minister has refused to provide those documents or information to the committee on grounds that the committee found to be quite unconvincing. The effect of that refusal has been that the committee is unable to conclude its inquiries under terms of references (d) and (f).

Until that information requested by the committee is provided by the government, the committee can only report in interim terms in relation to those two terms of reference. The committee believes that it is in the public interest for the requested information and documents to be made available to the committee. The committee believes that the minister's reasons for withholding the documents and information from the committee are specious, and therefore recommends to the Senate that the documents be provided to the committee.

The committee also believes that the many issues left unanswered could be resolved if the minister were to agree to the committee's request to appear before the committee. I indicate that tomorrow I will give notice of motion with respect to the production of documents and other matters raised in the committee's recommendations on these issues.

In conclusion, the committee found that DIFF was an important and effective element in Australia's aid program, which delivered significant humanitarian benefits to developing countries. It also assisted Australian companies by enabling them to compete on equal terms with overseas companies for development projects. Its abrupt termination has damaged our relationships with regional countries, undermined Australia's standing as a provider of humanitarian relief and compromised our commercial credibility in the region.

PARA.BREAK: Recipient governments will view with caution future commitments made by Australian governments. Australian companies will find it significantly more difficult to establish themselves and win contracts in the region. The implementation of the decision to terminate the scheme was clumsy and ill‐judged and has only confirmed the perception in some quarters that the government's commit ment to Asia is little more than lip service. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References committee on the abolition of the development import finance facility being tabled today comes in two parts: a majority report from the majority of Labor members on the committee and a minority report from the three coalition members. A minority report was considered necessary because the Labor members from the very beginning treated this inquiry as a political exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: Now this political emphasis is highlighted by their conclusion that they can only report in interim terms on two terms of reference. That is a ludicrous suggestion when the totality of evidence given in the inquiry is considered. This included direct responses from foreign governments and their ambassadors, including a press release dated 15 September from President Ramos of the Philippines issued `to rectify inaccurate newspaper responses', denying the decision to terminate DIFF had damaged relations between Australia and the Philippines, and pointing out `negotiations on funding mixed credit projects were going on between the National Economic and Development Authority and Australian aid officials'.

The allegations by Labor members of the committee that specific possible parliamentary question briefs, government to government correspondence and cables be revealed to the committee show that they have forgotten in a very short space of time the proper requirements of government. The opposition, only recently out of government, is now trying to tell the Senate that they do not understand that PPQs and government to government correspondence are the subject of confidentiality.

PARA.BREAK: The government acted in a proper manner in claiming that non-disclosure of such correspondence and information is in the national interest. The opposition members cried about the effects on foreign governments yet at the same time they want to force the government to commit acts that would be highly embar rassing to these same foreign governments. It is not right to ask the Senate to endorse their spurious reasons for not signing off on this report.

SPEECH.PARA: There was certainly no opportunity denied to the committee to have all aspects of the scheme and government advice examined and cross-examined. AusAID and DFAT officials answered around 900 questions on the issue. They were questioned for over nine hours on four separate occasions, as were other departments involved in the scheme.

The minister on his part made thorough disclosures to the parliament through his statement to the parliament on 26 June 1996 and his letter to the Speaker dated 19 July. Despite considerable opportunity provided to opposition members to question senior DFAT and AusAID officers, the statements from the minister remain unchallenged and uncontradicted.

The opposition members' delay represents not only hypocrisy of the highest order but also short‐term memory loss. Do they wish to deny the following statements of their leaders? Their former leader, Paul Keating, in a statement to the House of Representatives on 4 November 1992 stated:
There will be no House of Representatives Minister appearing before a Senate committee of any kind while ever I am Prime Minister, I can assure you.
Their present leader, Mr Beazley, on 7 October 1993 stated in a motion that the House:
. . . further resolves that it is not appropriate that any member of the House of Representatives be required to appear before a committee of the Senate against the member's will . . .

Whether they want to follow their defeated leader, Mr Keating, or their present leader, Mr Beazley, they have it from both that no House of Representatives minister is to appear before a Senate committee. How can they now claim the rules have changed with a change of government?

PARA.BREAK: The minority report acknowledges the significance of the DIFF scheme as a tied concessional aid scheme delivering aid into Asian markets. Government members accept overwhelmingly the evidence received from Australian companies in support of commercial benefits that flowed to individual com panies from DIFF funding. Evidence was given of the export opportunities and internationalisation of Australian businesses and the opportunities for the development of technology. Expert evidence confirmed the Australian scheme had been tightened up to meet its aid objectives, with 85 per cent of aid being at the instigation of foreign countries following the implementation of the Helsinki report. Evidence was also accepted by all committee members that the government had signalled the end of the DIFF scheme prior to the 2 March election.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Treasurer's press release on 15 February stated:
In government the government would terminate DIFF from the start of 1996‐97, thus achieving savings of $123.5 million alone.

The then shadow foreign affairs minister, Mr Downer, had also in the lead‐up to the election made many references to his desire for aid programs to have a greater focus on direct poverty alleviation and community based activities. The difficult budgetary position bequeathed to this government has been acknowledged in all quarters, including acknowledgment and understanding by foreign governments.

As contained in the report, the announcement to terminate the scheme was made on 8 May 1996. The minister received advice on the termination and, in accordance with the advice, announced that the government would fund projects with companies that held formal offers and earmarked funds for that purpose. This left 85 projects that had reached the letter of advice stage. In many cases, significant amounts had been spent not only by the companies but by suppliers, joint partners and foreign governments.

The scheme, which has been in operation since 1982, has always had long lead times, and statistics of the small percentage of projects that proceeded to formal offers and signed contracts in one year were confirmed in evidence. In July, a priority round of extra projects was announced, with $32 million allocated this financial year and the next, making a total of $64 million. A selection of priority programs is presently proceeding in cooperation with the participating foreign countries.

Government members believe the additional funding should go a long way to satisfying many of the projects that have reached the letter of advice stage and would have proceeded to a formal offer. Government members support wholeheartedly the government's independent and comprehensive review of Australia's aid program, to be chaired by Paul Simons, that was announced by the minister on 28 May, plus government ministers' statements on the possibility of a soft loans program as early as 1997‐98.

Subject to budget constraints, we believe there is a role for soft loan or tied concessional finance as a mechanism for delivering humanitarian focused aid. We have made reference to the Simons review to consider aspects arising from this inquiry. These include determining the multiplier effect, the flow‐on of trade, export opportunities and other commercial benefits to individual companies and the net economy.

The extent to which concessional finance advantages companies so they enter new export markets and internationalise their business, the extent to which the scheme can deliver positive development outcomes, and whether Australian companies would suffer any competitive disadvantage in the Asia‐Pacific region from exclusion from a concessional finance package are the important aspects for the future of a concessional finance scheme as a form of delivery for Australia's aid program—not the furphies and hypocrisies of the opposition members, who know full well that lengthy evidence confirmed the proper behaviour of the minister in revealing all within the constraints of the national and public interest.
We also recommend that the Senate should accept this report as final. Any delay is only to accommodate the purely political purposes of the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 June this year, I moved the motion which set up this inquiry and I participated in all the sessions of it. I wish to make a few remarks about its report.

BREAK.PARA: Before I turn to them, can I just say to Senator Boswell, my colleague opposite, that in the Watergate hearings thousands of hours of tape were produced as evidence but 9½ minutes were missing. It was that missing 9½ minutes which were critical to the judgment as to what the executive in that circumstance had done.

It is certainly true that DFAT has produced a wealth of material. In summary, it comes down to this: the questions we referred to the officer of the department were then referred on to the minister and we got no answer. When we wrote to the minister, the minister said the department had answered the questions. We are caught in that circular bind. It is the missing 9½ minutes—if I can use that example—that is the question here when it comes to the role of the minister and the role of his office in fielding issues related to this inquiry.

Can I say, first of all, that my thanks go to the secretariat for the fine job that they have done and all who have made submissions to this inquiry, including both DFAT and AusAID. This is a major inquiry. The details have been given about it by other speakers in this debate. By my count, overall, 49 people represented themselves or organisations to give evidence before the inquiry and there were a large number of written submissions.

The people who came forward to give evidence were mostly major companies in Australia. Some of those companies are household names, but most of them are small to medium sized companies struggling to develop a foothold for themselves in the international marketplace. The inquiry commanded extensive media coverage and it was a major political event during its life. In broadbanding it, can I say that the Australian business community, who gathered here in numbers to present their views about the termination of DIFF, did so by emphasising a number of points.

The way in which the DIFF scheme was terminated by the minister certainly did, if you take your line across all of the evidence, embarrass Australian companies in overseas marketplaces. It embarrassed the business partners of those companies in Australia and overseas. It embarrassed the governments with whom they dealt and caused financial loss to many Australian companies—losses which were quite large. It caused the companies in Australia that supported those overseas companies and the recipient companies working as partners to the Australian companies in overseas marketplaces significant financial loss, not to mention the loss of trust.

We all know that in working in the Asia-Pacific area one builds up by strong, long commercial relationships as a common coin of trade and negotiation the element of trust. The evidence of the Australian companies to this inquiry was that this very important element of trust was broken by the way in which this government terminated the report. They will be struggling now to re-establish that trust because, whether we like it or not, in those countries what the government does is seen as what the private sector is committed to as well. While they will be trying to resurrect their reputation and distance themselves from the government, irreparable damage has been done to them by the way in which this scheme was cancelled.

It is also important to note that DIFF was tightened by the OECD. What we are now talking about is a better focused scheme where the problems have been largely eliminated. You cannot compare the complaints and criticisms of DIFF in the past with the scheme that is operating now because the new scheme operates without complaint and efficiently and delivers on the humanitarian and poverty alleviation fronts as well.

It is a scheme which, on all of the evidence, has helped Australian companies establish themselves in foreign marketplaces and has led to follow on work and contracts for them which they win on a fully commercial business basis and results in a growth in Australian exports to the region. This scheme is very important at both a foreign relations aid level as well as at a commercial level—although the scheme does not commercially support Australia, it is targeted at foreign needs.

There is a minority report contained in the committee report. Government members have put in a defensive report to protect the government from the criticism that flowed very freely in the hearings. It must also be said that the existence of the minority report confirms some of the problems and criticisms that the opposition and the minor parties had about the cancellation of the DIFF scheme. The recommendations of the government members call for an enlargement of the terms of reference of the Simons inquiry to take account of many of the issues that were raised properly and legitimately in this hearing.

The government members' minority report and its recommendations are in a perverse way a tribute to the efficacy of this inquiry and the need for it. I think the most important thing the government should do now as a consequence of the evidence we have adduced over several sitting days, and which resulted in volumes of Hansard, is honour all of the letters of advice that were given to Australian companies that they were in the pipeline and could continue to the next phase. It is absolutely commercially important that the government does that.

In the minority report, the government members of this committee said that there will be a fallout rate of about 25 per cent. If there is, the cost to the government at the end of day will be that amount less. The financial savings which the government has so craved by cancelling the scheme in the brutal way it did can still be made. But justice and honour will be done. Those Australian companies that have letters of advice telling them that they can proceed to the next commercial phase should get final letters of approval. If there is that attrition and fallout rate it will be done fairly. It will not be done by ministerial fiat. It will be done with well established rules. They will be filtered out according to the traditions of the scheme. That is absolutely important. I think it is important that Solarex be added to the scheme because that involves the rural electrification program in Indonesia. It is a program that ought to be considered in this whole package.

The Downer round—the round introduced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to compensate for the criticism that he has rightly attracted—is a recognition that the government has mishandled this matter. He has gone about solving the problem in the wrong way. The right solution is the one recommended in this report—that is, to allow the companies to be tested in the normal commercial way by AusAID and if they succeed give them a tick and if they do not eliminate them.

The other thing about this report is that it is incomplete. We are unable to report to the Senate on the reference that the Senate conferred on us and therefore we have not been able to discharge the Senate's obligation. We have not been able to because the minister has not appeared before this inquiry and he has not presented material to this inquiry necessary for us to discharge the remit given to us by the Senate.

This is a serious matter. I believe that the minister should make the material available now. The recommendations in the report call for that and I support them absolutely. On 7 October 1993, in a debate in the House of Representatives on a motion calling upon a minister of the then government to appear before a Senate committee, the now Minister for Foreign Affairs, who refuses to appear before this committee, said:
I believe that the Treasurer should appear before the committee to give evidence. He should tell the committee what he knew at the time of the preparation of the budget papers last year.

He goes on to argue why members of the House of Representatives should appear before Senate committees when Senate committees are inquiring into public affairs which are of national importance. He makes a case against the motion moved in the House of Representatives on that day by the then government which was that ministers should not appear before Senate committees.

Mr Downer said at that time that ministers should appear. All I ask is that he conform to his own standard. He set that standard then. He is now hiding behind it. He is running away from appearing now. He should come forward and appear before the committee.

I have the results of a survey, conducted by Australian business, looking at their view of the minister's handling of this cancellation. It is universally condemnatory of the minister and is an expression of a lack of confidence in his ability to handle this matter properly. The only way the minister can deal with the big question mark placed over his head by Australian business is to clear the record, appear before the Senate inquiry, adduce the material and allow the Senate to complete its reference and report to this chamber. I ask the minister to take heed of that advice and comply with it. I recommend this very good report to the Senate. It sets out all of the details necessary for the public at large and this chamber to come to a conclusion about the termination of the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to take part in this debate. Coming from the state of Tasmania, Mr Acting Deputy President Calvert, you would know the importance of the forest industry and what these new regulations mean to the ordinary men and women of rural and regional Tasmania and its townships—such as Burnie, Smithton, Triabunna and now even Bridgewater, where the new mill is operated by the Briggs family.

SPEECH.PARA: I am astounded that the Australian Labor Party are joining forces with the Greens on this matter. Indeed, the CFMEU—the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union—have told the people of Australia what they think of the ALP's actions in backing the Greens' motion. They have described it variously as a `sad joke' and as the ALP having `learnt nothing from its previous mismanagement of forest policy'. Mr Smith, the spokesman for this union, said:

The ALPs lack of understanding of the importance of the forest and forest products industry to regional Australia coupled with its willingness to use the industry as a political football will ensure that voters especially those in regional Australia will continue to keep the ALP in opposition.
He went on to say:
. . . the defeat of the Coalition's export regulations would open up the opportunity for a welcomed increase in woodchip exports.

But of course the downside is that we would not have the capacity for three-year grants of licences. The union then went on to make a very perceptive comment. They suggested to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, that it would be best if he:

. . . reallocated shadow portfolios so that the Shadow Environment Minister Carmen Lawrence and Shadow Resource Minister Neal O'Keefe were given other responsibilities more in tune with their obvious limited abilities.

That is the view of the CFMEU. The fact is that they have got it absolutely right. Those opposite know that this union on this occasion got the facts absolutely right when they said that the Australian Labor Party would remain in opposition because of this.

It may be of interest to honourable senators to note the comments made by Gary Gray, the national secretary of the ALP; Barry Jones, the national president of the ALP; and Senator Sue Mackay. They delivered a report on the 2 March 1996 election to the Labor Party faithful in August this year. In that document, under the heading `Priorities/balance' the first issue they raised was `Woodchips, jobs and environment'. What did these people say about their own party? They said:
The logging dispute and the blockade of Parliament exposed seemingly intractable conflicts between two of Labor's important constituencies, workers and environmentalists.

Clearly, the Australian Labor Party at the last election were trying to straddle a barbed wire fence, and we know what happens to people who sit on barbed wire fences—especially when they get pushed off. What the Labor Party have done on this occasion is jump on to the Greens' side and thereby desert the workers.

Last Sunday I had the opportunity to visit the electorate of Paterson, which is now so ably represented by Mr Bob Baldwin. I had the honour of providing a message from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to the assembled throng of approximately 2,000 people in the township of Stroud. The Prime Minister had indicated his support and the benefits that would flow to that community in northern New South Wales—and to all communities around Australia—from these excellent export woodchip regulations.

In that community, the mood was that the ALP had sold them out on the issue of the forest industry. They had sold out the societies in these little townships. They had sold out the men and women. They had sold out the children. They had sold out the small townships and the small businesses.

The ALP report was not the only one to recognise the fact that the Labor Party stance on woodchips cost them a lot of votes at the last election—the New South Wales presentation also made the same comment. Under the broad heading `Campaign' and the subheading `Strategy', some perceptive comments were made by Terry Sheahan, the president of the New South Wales branch of the ALP and the chair of the federal election consultative committee, and Chris Raper, the vice-president of the New South Wales branch of the ALP.

It is interesting to note that that committee consisted of such luminaries as Jim Snow, the former member for Eden-Monaro; Robert Tickner, the former member for Hughes; Bob Horne, the former member for Paterson; Maggie Deahm, the former member for Macquarie; and Paul Elliott, the former member for Parramatta. And the list goes on. Why are they all former members? Let us see what the report said. What does it tell us? That report said:
. . . a number of issues involving Ministers during the final term of the Government (eg Carmen Lawrence, The White Board affair and woodchipping) had damaged the image of the Party.

If you recall, the Carmen Lawrence incident was a situation where a minister of the Crown had been found to have lied under oath, and she was allowed to retain her ministerial commission. The whiteboard affair related to Ms Ros Kelly who—`administered' would be an incorrect word—misappropriated millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds in what became known as the sports rorts affair. Both incidents are a very sad reflection on ministerial responsibility.

The ALP in New South Wales put woodchipping into the same category as the Carmen Lawrence and Ros Kelly affairs. Why? Because what the Labor Party was doing was blatantly and utterly dishonest and of no benefit to the workers that they allegedly represent. To a certain extent, I suppose I ought be cheerful and thank the ALP for once again selling out the workers to enable us to continue to garner the support of the blue-collar workers in seats such as Patterson and others in New South Wales and in Victoria.

What we really need is an understanding of the benefits of these new regulations. It is all about security of resource. What will be the benefit of this security of resource? It will allow investment in this country. The Greens come to us all the time and say, `We oppose woodchip exports because the timber ought be kept in Australia and create Australian jobs.' But coming from the state of Tasmania, I know the game they play. Wesley Vale—they opposed it. They then formed a Green‐Labor accord government, and a project that was destined for the Huon in my home state was bought out with taxpayers' money to ensure that there would not be a use and harnessing of the resources. As a result, this condemned the people of the Huon area to ongoing unemployment.

We now have a third project developing for the north of Tasmania and once again the Greens say, `We will support it if there's no pollution.' My goodness! Each time the honourable senator opposite gets into a car, pollution is caused. He himself does not abide by the same standards that he would seek to put onto a woodchip mill in Tasmania or the production of medium density fibreboard.

PARA.BREAK: Let us have a look at what has really been happening. The general uncertainty over forest policy in this country has had a massively destabilising impact on investment in this important industry. We frequently hear of literally billions of dollars of investment which would flow, in the main, to rural and regional areas—creating much needed em ployment—if there was greater security over resource supply to the forest based industries.

SPEECH.PARA: These problems are to be addressed through the establishment of regional forest agreements which, in addition to establishing a comprehensive, adequate and representative—CAR—forest reserve system, will provide the basis for an internationally competitive, ecologically sustainable, value adding, native forest based industry. Woodchips have been the public face of the forest debate in this country for many years. The arrangements under which they are exported—like it or not—are fundamental to the investment equation.

The massive damage done to the timber industry last year by Labor's foolhardy two-stage licensing system should not be underestimated. The two‐stage licensing process resulted in key customers sourcing part of their needs from other suppliers because there was no guarantee they could secure supplies beyond the 80 per cent allowed in the first-stage licence. The customers never came back, nor did the jobs. The security which will be provided by the three-year licences under the new regulations will help our exporters restore Australia's credibility as a reliable supplier with obvious flow-ons for regional employment.

The new regulations made by this government provide greater security for the timber industry in a number of ways. Firstly, they restore the licence volume stripped without any logical policy justification last year and, with it, hundreds of jobs. Secondly, they recognise the reality of native forest logging operations in this country—that they are driven by the need to provide logs for the sawmilling and value adding sector.

While a substantial proportion of the logs harvested are not of milling quality, good management practice in many of our forests demands that logging residues are removed so that the forests can regenerate. The alternative to removing the pulpwood is to burn it or leave it to rot on the forest floor. Both of these actions have negative environmental impacts and they just do not make economic sense.

BREAK.PARA: I ask the young people in the gallery upstairs: how could it be environmentally sound to burn literally millions of tonnes of forest waste on the forest floor rather than export them? Surely it would be better to use that resource, get jobs for young people in this country and get some money back into Australia to ensure that the people who are represented upstairs in the gallery are not left with a huge legacy of debt that Labor left them with. It is absolutely vital—
