It is always so telling, isn't it, when you are really striking the point, when you are really making the runs. That is when those opposite, feeling the pressure, get up with frivolous points of order to try to stop the flow of debate. I want to make the point again, through you this time, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is environmental vandalism to allow millions of tonnes of timber waste to rot or burn on the forest floor rather than using it.

BREAK.PARA: If we don't use Australian forest waste, Mr Acting Deputy President, do you know what will happen? The world markets will rape the forests of South‐East Asia and South America. The question is: who has the best forest practices—Australia or some of these South‐East Asian or South American countries? Methinks the honourable senator knows the answer to that but he will not have the guts to tell us.

What makes sense is for this wood to be sold to help pay the wages of logging and haulage contractors, sawmill workers and other people employed directly and indirectly in the industry. Senator Lees, in her speech on the second reading of the Native Forest Protection Bill, made the point:
. . . export woodchipping enables the native forest industry to spread its costs over a wider base and without this native forest logging would not continue in many areas.

What Senator Lees was conceding was that the harvesting and supply of pulpwood is an integral part of an integrated, value‐adding native forest based industry. Indeed, the production of woodchips is, in itself, a value‐adding activity. The value added is the difference between selling the wood for export and leaving it to waste and rot on the forest floor or simply to be burnt.

These regulations also deliver specific benefits to sawmill operators. For the first time we have a licence category which applies to sawmill residues. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, coming from Tasmania, will recall how the Greens used to beat their chests in Tasmania and say, `You've got to look after the small sawmillers; they are the ones who are hurting.' Well, the small sawmillers support these export wood regulations, don't they? They think they are a great idea.

But where are the Greens embracing the sawmillers now? They cannot be seen anywhere because the bluff of the Greens has been called. We as a government have recognised the importance of looking after the small sawmillers and the Greens want to shut them down as well, once the pressure is put on. We have applied the blowtorch to their bellies and now they come out and say that these sawmill residues should not be allowed to be sold; in other words, the small sawmillers ought to be thrown on the economic scrap heap.

All processing operations, including sawmills, produce waste material. If they are not certain they can dispose of the waste, for example by selling it as woodchips, the viability of their operation is undermined. When we look at value‐added forest industry investment proposals, the capacity to dispose of waste economically is a critical factor in the final decision as to whether the investment goes ahead. If the only outlet for these woodchips is a massively oversupplied domestic market, the investment must be at risk as will, as a result, job opportunities and the lifeblood of a lot of our small towns throughout regional Australia.

The current woodchip export licences contain conditions which require exporters to source woodchips from sawmills as a first preference. Surely the Greens must applaud that but, no, they do not. They want to dispose of these regulations. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) has confirmed that these conditions will be retained in new licences, giving added strength to our commitment to value adding and job creation. These regulations ensure exporters will seek out sawmills as their first priority source of woodchip.

Additionally, the one million tonne category under which sawmill residues may be exported also covers silvicultural thinnings, the wood produced from thinning regrowth forests to improve their future sawlog yield. We thought the Greens and the Labor Party were all in favour of plantations but the Greens are attempting to overthrow today in the Senate even those regulations that will assist plantations. So their commitment is not to plantations, just as it is not to sawmills.

Giving special treatment to silvicultural thinnings will result in the industry having at its disposal in the future a wood resource that provides a higher proportion of the high quality logs ideally suited to value adding. Many people in Australia would be surprised to learn that we as a country run up a $2 billion deficit in wood products. In other words, the amount of wood product we export is exceeded by $2 billion by the amount we import. There is a trade deficit in wood products.

What these regulations are trying to do is allow us to export some of our waste to repair that imbalance. More importantly, the three‐year licensing will provide resource security. Once that resource security is there, people from the international community will look upon us a lot more favourably for investment. Once investments are here in this country we will have the benefit of even further value adding and even more jobs. That is what these regulations are designed to do.

I compliment the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) for his excellent article on page 15 of the Age of Tuesday, 17 September 1996. Anybody who is genuinely interested in hearing the facts of the forest debate ought to read this article. In the concluding minute can I simply say that those who are concerned about wildlife ought to be reminded that the Greenpeace founder, Dr Patrick Moore, recently stated that there was not one proven instance of an animal species becoming extinct due to commercial forestry.

That challenge has been thrown out to the Greens on a number of occasions. I did it to former Senator Chamarette. She was unable to respond. What we have had in this debate is a lot of mischief. I urge the Senate, especially those who still have an open mind on this issue, to support the regulations for jobs and investment in this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak against this motion brought on by Senator Brown. I really believe that Senator Brown has little idea of the extent of the effect of his motion on the lives of those involved in the forestry industry in creating both anxiety and distress. Senator Brown was voted into parliament to represent Tasmania; yet, by his actions I believe he is prepared to sacrifice jobs in our state and forestry workers' dignity and livelihood in so many remote regional areas—not only in Tasmania but in so many forestry areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike Senator Brown, I take the problems of regional Australia and the forestry industries very seriously. I will represent them, I will not dismiss their concerns and I will not turn my back on them. They are people whose needs have to be met. I am interested in people all around Australia being able to earn a decent living by working in the forest industries under appropriate environmental guidelines. I believe in sustainable management in our forests.

BREAK.PARA: Yesterday Senator Brown attempted to intimidate me into abstaining from voting on his motion because of a token holding in both Boral and North Ltd. Both companies are involved in resource development and have subsidiaries in timber harvesting. North is essentially a mining company. I do not hold any ministerial or executive position, and my holding is fractional in relation to the capitalisation of both companies. The capitalisation of those companies, I remind the Senate, runs into tens of millions of dollars. So the opportunity for exploitation or profit by me in my vote on this issue is absolutely minuscule. Therefore, I think that objectivity has to be brought into this debate. On the other hand, I do abhor the intimidatory tactics of you, Senator Brown, on this issue.

I would have planted more trees than perhaps any other person in this place—certainly more than Senator Brown. Even before Senator Brown set foot in Tasmania I was working behind the scenes to improve certain forestry practices—with a high degree of success, I must say. I think it is indeed unfortunate that Senator Brown continues to misrepresent or recount those bad practices of 15 to 20 years ago as if they are commonplace today. I remind the Senate that nowadays Tasmania has some of the most advanced forestry practices in the world.

For the purpose of the record, I have to state that also from time to time I have interest in woodchips and forestry as a primary producer. Among the reasons that my constituents have placed their confidence in me over the years is my experience, my knowledge, my interest and my strong representation in both forestry and agriculture. My interests have enabled me to represent my constituents in an informed and sensitive manner.

Tasmania has a huge resource in its forests. In addition to its native forests, thousands of hectares of plantations have been established both by Forestry Tasmania and privately. Timber is a renewable resource. It is a sustainable resource that could bring so much benefit to Tasmanians but, by his motion, Senator Brown is hell‐bent on preventing the creation of more job opportunities. No wonder Tasmania's unemployment is the highest in Australia—and Senator Brown largely has to carry the cross for that high unemployment rate.

We all know that sawlogs are felled under legitimate and carefully managed logging operations nowadays, and these sawlogs are cut from the main trunks of the trees. The sawlogs are used for fine furniture and decor such as we have in this parliament. The remainder of the trunk, the branches and the thinnings are most likely to be left on the forest floor. Unfortunately, there is little market for them. This residue can be left to rot or sent up in smoke, as my colleague Senator Abetz said, in order to clear the forest floor for further plantations. How can we condone such mismanagement of a precious resource? How could I as a duly elected representative of the people abstain from voting on this ridiculous motion which has far‐reaching consequences and allow these potential export earnings to rot on the forest floor, or to go up in smoke, when there are valuable export markets for these products?

To expedite the generation of new trees, eucalypts respond quickly to fire. Often the leftovers have been left on the forest floor or are burnt, sending off clouds of smoke and contributing to the carbon dioxide levels in our atmosphere. Does Senator Brown believe that this is the right way to go? If he were interested in anything other than getting his name splashed across the front pages of newspapers, to the detriment of others, he would be working towards a sustainable and balanced solution. But we do not see this. Instead, he knocks forest management practices, he knocks selected sawlogging, he knocks downstream processing and in so doing he knocks the economy to pieces.

My colleagues, that is not all. You may have noted in his declaration of interests that travel and accommodation costs to and in Taiwan were paid for by none other than the Meinung Environmentalists. The trip to Taiwan was not to encourage a company to set up an operation to do more downstream processing of woodchips in Tasmania but to hinder that development. He does not even want Tasmanians to get a job processing woodchips into pulp or paper in Tasmania, the state that he represents. I draw your attention to a headline `Taiwan Pulp Ready to Abandon Australia' in the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday 26 June:
Taiwan Pulp and Paper Corp has said it will look for an alternative site overseas if opposition from environmentalists forces changes to its plan to build a $1.2 billion pulp mill in Tasmania.

Senator Brown therefore goes to Taiwan, courtesy of the environmentalists, to jeopardise the development of downstream processing in Tasmania. More jobs could potentially be lost, and he has been voted to represent Tasmanians.

To the other vested interests he has declared, Senator Brown by his own logic is the one I believe who should abstain from voting on this motion. Senator Brown, who tries to smear the integrity of anyone who opposes his view, is an office holder or financial contributor of $200 or more in any single calendar year to none other than the Bush Heritage Fund and the Wilderness Society. Based on his own reasoning of why some senators should abstain from voting on this motion, he should also abstain because of his vested interests in environmental movements. So I say: what stupidity.
I am surprised at the action of the Labor Party in supporting Senator Brown. It is not surprising that the CFMEU attacks the ALP on its woodchip confusion. A press release dated 14 October states:

The National Secretary of the Construction Forestry Mining Energy Union's Forestry Division Mr Trevor Smith branded the ALP Federal Parliamentary Party a "sad joke" today over its decision to oppose the Coalition's export woodchip regulations.
Mr Smith said the ALP had learnt nothing from its previous mismanagement of forest policy and would continue to pay a high price for its inability to learn.

"The ALP's lack of understanding of the importance of the forest and forest products industry to regional Australia coupled with its willingness to use the industry as a political football will ensure that voters especially those in regional Australia will continue to keep the ALP in opposition" Mr Smith said.
The Union claimed that the defeat of the Coalition's export regulations would open up the opportunity for a welcome increase in woodchip exports.

"To see the ALP politically grandstand against the Government's export woodchip regulations on the basis that it is opposed to an increase in the woodchip ceiling is a completely illogical approach. A defeat of the Government regulations would see the current export woodchip ceiling removed" Mr Smith said.

The Union advised ALP leader Kim Beazley that he would be in a better position to build ALP support in Regional Australia if he reallocated shadow portfolios so that the Shadow Environment Minister Carmen Lawrence and Shadow Resource Minister Neal O'Keefe were given other responsibilities more in tune with their obvious limited abilities.
What an indictment from one of the biggest supporting unions of the ALP in relation to this particular industry.

As honourable senators would be aware, there is a current ceiling of 5.251 million tonnes applying to all woodchips and this will continue under these regulations. An additional quantity of one million tonnes of woodchips are to be sourced exclusively from mill residues, and silvicultural thinnings form regrowth forests will also be allowed. Good forestry practice, I would have thought. In addition, there will be a case by case approval for the export of woodchips to be sourced from the clearing of degraded private forests for the establishment of hardwood plantations.

This type of woodchip export would not fall within the ceiling. They would be permitted only if the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), in consultation with the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), were satisfied that the forest in question did not contain high conservation values which could potentially meet shortfalls in a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

This decision is not one that has just been dreamt up. It is the result of extensive consultations with all of the stakeholders and represents a balanced approach to a very complex issue. It is a firm and balanced decision, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for the Environment said in a joint statement on 11 July. It is a firm and balanced decision on behalf of the entire Australian community in the national interest. It is a decision for the environment, for greater security and for jobs.

Woodchips will continue to be exported under the regional forest agreements but it is not a case of open slather. There are controls, and very stringent controls. The industry will be very carefully managed to address the interests of all sides. The strategy is one that is integrated. It allows for the long-term sustainability of our forests and enables us to maintain our international competitiveness. It enables the industry to plan ahead and use our natural resources efficiently and effectively while bringing long-term benefits to industry and conservationists alike.

What Senator Brown must face is that, in a sinister attempt to smear fellow senators and cut job opportunities in regional Australia, he is clearing the way for open slather on the amount that woodchip companies could export. What we could have in these regulations is a plan for sustainability and predictability in the forest industry, an opportunity for thousands of Australians to get real work and an opportunity for Australia to compete on world markets now and in the future. These regulations should not be disallowed, and I urge senators not to follow Senator Brown's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I should declare my interest in this debate for the information of other honourable senators. I am currently the state president of the forest division of the CFMEU in Tasmania. I guess I would be able to lay claim to representing one of the most important stakeholders in this debate: the workers in the industry. From that point of view, it is clear where I am coming from. I am totally committed to a prosperous industry and to the workers of the industry. I guess my record will attest to that. I will approach this debate from a significantly different approach and objective to that of Senator Brown. I will be supporting the disallowance motion, but I will do so on the basis of arguing a completely different approach.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I am committed to ensuring the industry achieves its full potential, to seeing our current trade deficit—which has been spoken about in this place—in wood and paper products significantly reduced or maybe even turned into a net trade surplus. Quite frankly, I believe we can achieve that.

If we do achieve that, we will create hundreds, if not thousands, of jobs for Australians, which will in turn generate significant wealth and benefits for this country. Unfortunately, I regret to say that the debate relating to forestry issues has always had political overtones. Little or no commonsense and logic have ever been applied to decisions that have been taken, especially as they relate to export woodchips.

I can say that these regulations do nothing to alleviate that problem. These regulations are, in some respect, no different from those which previously applied. They are iniquitous and they weaken the previous criteria for downstream processing in this country. A key objective of any regulations or other regulatory measures ought to be to improve things, to bring about a better industry—one that maximises the utilisation of a very valuable resource and enhances the employment and wealth generating opportunities for the people of this country.

Of course, it should go without saying that regulations should and must take account of environmental requirements. These proposed regulations achieve none of these things. All the government has done is increase the ceiling—or, in fact, not have a ceiling—and substantially weaken the downstream processing aspects of the previous regulations. It has broadened the interpretations, particularly as they relate to degraded forests and other environmental aspects, such that they are almost meaningless.

I just want to take some time to remind the Senate of what is happening in the industry and what has happened to date. If you look at the history of my home state of Tasmania, on which I can probably speak with more authority than any other state, you will find that we had an industry that developed primarily as a sawmilling industry. Sawmills were supplied with sawlogs that were taken out of forests essentially on a selective logging program. They were set up to cut very high quality timber.

BREAK.PARA: What happened in the mid‐ to late 1970s was that they realised that because they did not have the technology and the equipment to access some of the then remaining areas of high quality forests, they had to reduce significantly the volume of sawlog, particularly the category 1 sawlog, that was being supplied to the industry. They cut it by some 50 per cent. We then saw the introduction of woodchip licences, which were, at that time, designed to utilise what were residues from sawmilling operations, both in the form of head logs and the squaring of round timber.

That was a long time ago. We had two categories of sawlog in Tasmania—category 1 and category 2. We had veneer logs that were provided to the veneer industry. With the advent of woodchip licences and the export of woodchips, we have seen a dramatic increase over the years in the volume of timber taken from the forests of Tasmania. We have seen a decrease in the volume of sawlogs in category 1 and category 2 that are supplied to the industry. I think what has happened in my state is that the industry, particularly the Forestry Commission of Tasmania, has got itself caught in a situation where, because its revenue is generated from the sale of forest products, it is in a volume driven, revenue driven cycle.

If you also look at the old industry—if I can describe it in that way—it never had the technology or the expertise to cut some timber species. There was a legitimate argument for exporting some of those species of trees that they could not cut or dry and process satisfactorily. The other realisation that hit some of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission people in the face—the people responsible for the management of the state's forests—was that they were taking out the best trees, they had degraded forests left, to some degree, and they really had no plantation or regeneration program of any real worth being put in place. So they decided that they would have to embark upon a silvicultural regime that led to clear‐felling. In some areas, that has an application. I would argue that it has not been best applied, in many cases, in Tasmania. But all of those things added to the burden.

If we just take one giant step forward to now, the reality is that not much has changed. We are still cutting down high volumes; we still have only two categories of sawlog in Tasmania—although some would argue that we have three; we now have a category 8, which is supposedly top end grade pulp logs. The other thing that has happened is that we now have the technology and the expertise to mill and process many of the species and types and qualities of logs that we once could not utilise simply because the technology and the expertise were not available. But it is now available.

What we see is the continuation of sending to woodchip mills logs that should actually be utilised in a way that I think will both prolong and enhance the value of Tasmania's forests—and this can also have equal application particularly in the states of Victoria and New South Wales—and this country's forests. We will achieve far greater benefits from the point of view of both employment and wealth generated if we make some changes to what is currently the pathetic way in which the timber of this country is being utilised.

If we look at how these regulations might go towards achieving that, I want to first go to the most recent regulations which were disallowed—the ones that operated when we were in government—and look at the requirements that were placed on applicants for woodchip licences. One particular aspect of the former regulations related to the applicant's commitment to value adding and processing activities in Australia, both now and in the future. That was designed to ensure that we started to focus, albeit in a very small way, on greater downstream processing in this country. I have listened to many members and senators say, `We want a pulp and paper mill in Australia. We want TPPC to build one, and we want this and we want that', and that government policy ought to reflect the opportunities and the stability to achieve that. I agree with that. But we do not see it in these regulations.

I turn to the problems this country has with the commitment of major exporters to downstream processing. I can give some examples of what the major players have done in the past to get themselves into a position where they can comply with the requirements of obtaining an export licence. There is the case of North Broken Hill and the games that I believe they play in making announcements about their commitment to downstream processing. They have done this year in, year out. Yet we have seen no real change, no real commitment to downstream processing in this country.

Some few years back North Broken Hill took a decision that they were a resource supplier. I do not have any contention with that. If that is their position, that is fine. But I do not believe that it ought to be acceptable in the public interest that this Senate and this parliament accept that we allow companies which clearly flout the rules of the day to get away with it. We have a responsibility to the community as a whole to ensure that, if we have resources, benefits are maximised from them.

By way of example I want to refer to a couple of press releases which were put out in late 1995 prior to the issuing of the 1996 licences. North Ltd issued one on 27 September 1995 headed `The pre‐feasibility for MDF plant at Triabunna'. It states:
North Forest Products today announced a pre‐feasibility study for a medium density fibre board plant at Triabunna, the first such plant in southern Tasmania.

Of course it paints a very rosy picture. I do not know how you have a pre‐feasibility study into a feasibility study, but I am quite sure North have done nothing about this. This was just grandstanding. What they did not tell us was that with regard to MDF plants you need a reasonable supply of water. Triabunna always has a real problem with water, even for the town water supply. I do not know where North intended to get the water from, but I do know this: they never intended and never will intend to build an MDF plant. It is a charade that should be brought to an end. A further press release of 22 September 1995 is headed: `North opens Tamar flitch mill'. It states:

North Forest Products today announced the operation of a flitch mill at its Tamar export woodchip mill at Longreach north of Launceston. The flitch mill will be managed by North, be operated by employees at the Tamar mill and use equipment currently on site.

Of course it will. It did open. It used to be open before and it opened again, but it closed three months later. It does not operate today. The blokes who were working it are not working it today. There are no flitches being cut and nothing is being achieved with regard to any commitment to downstream processing. Again, it was a charade.

The other major company involved in exports of woodchips from this country is Boral. We read, `Boral may set up flitch mill'; `Boral eyeing north-west sites'; `Boral's announcement on Thursday that it had agreed with Forestry Tasmania to feasibility studies'. They are not going to have a pre‐feasibility study, just a direct feasibility study. We read that they are `examining a $100 million hardboard factory, a $10 million recovery sawmill at Longreach and a $10 million veneer plant. But I do not think there has been any feasibility study with regard to those things either. They again just represent some grandstanding with regard to the former criteria. Those criteria did require the applicant to give some demonstration of commitment to value adding and processing in Australia, both now and in the future. The minister's statement on hardwood export policy says:

Export licence conditions have been included to give priority (in decreasing order) to woodchips sourced from sawmill residues, reject logs, logging residues, silvicultural thinnings and silvicultural residues (these terms are defined in Attachment D). About 2 million tonnes of woodchips sourced from sawmill residues will be exported in 1996 . . .
That figure of two million tonnes represented about 40 per cent of the total volume that was proposed to be exported from Australia in 1996. That being the case, the statement goes on to say:
The Government is committed to ensuring that the proportion of exports not derived from genuine value‐adding activities is decreased over time. The ultimate goal is to maximise domestic processing.
The Government will continue to favour value‐adding proposals when assessing woodchip licence applications. . .

That was a situation where we took a very small step. When we were in government I was always critical of our approach in dealing with woodchip licences. But we did take a very small step towards beginning to get companies to value add and downstream process in this country. I wish to give an example of how I think the industry in Tasmania—I have said this before—is either corrupt or so pathetically managed that it is incomprehensible.

In 1992, a person named Al Corbet came to see me. He is a Queenslander who has a company called Asia Pacific Resources. He had a proposal to set up three flitch mills in Tasmania. They would have utilised about half a million tonnes of logs that were then being chipped. He went to the Forestry Commission with that proposal and also to the Tasmanian Development Authority. The Forestry Commission said to him that they were somewhat sceptical about his view regarding the potential recovery. I add that all of those flitches were to be exported. It was a totally export oriented proposal. None of them would have been sold on the domestic market.

The Forestry Commission said a few things. It was sceptical about his claim regarding what could be recovered. He conducted some trials to prove that. He also received a letter from the Forestry Commission. This is why I say it is critically important that, at a federal level, where we have a capacity to determine how the industry will be driven in terms of value adding and downstream processing, and we only have it through the Export Control Act, we at least do something about it. This is a really good example.

The Forestry Commission said to Mr Corbet, `Fine, we'll sell you the logs. If, at the end of the day, you can prove that what you say is right, we'll sell you the logs. But what you have to do is go to see North Broken Hill and you have to seek an arrangement with them that will allow you to sell the residue from the processing of those logs.' Of course, when you are processing low grade logs, you always get a higher percentage of residue.

In that letter the Forestry Commission also said that his negotiations with North Broken Hill must not interfere in any way with the current arrangements that existed between Forestry Tasmania—what was then the Forestry Commission—and the particular company; indeed, it must not reduce the quality of that company's exports, that is, its chips.

You have to question: what are we really on about? What is Forestry Tasmania on about? As Senator Hill or Senator Parer said yesterday, the states have the responsibility for the way in which forests are managed and harvested. That is true, but if we see things that are wrong or if we see that there are not practices in place and there are not efforts being made at a state level to guarantee that this country maximises its opportunities from its forest based industries, we ought to do something about it. As I said, we do have the capacity under the Export Control Act to do that.

But it did not stop there in terms of this person. He owns a sawmill on the north‐west coast of Tasmania called Precise Timbers. That is what it used to be called. He completely rebuilt it. He sought to purchase logs from Forestry and also from North to supply that mill. Twenty‐five people could have been employed. His access to the mill was across crown land. The minister of the day sold the land to another sawmill owner next door who took out an injunction to stop access to this mill.

Forestry Tasmania said, `Well, you are not a complying mill now because you have no access.' Of course, who owned the sawmill that acquired the land? It was a former management employee of North Broken Hill. You have to wonder, if there is not collusion somewhere there, why it is that somebody who says `I want to employ 25 people, I want to run a sawmill, I've got a sale for the timber' cannot get the sawmill up and running.

It does not stop there, either. He proposed to build a sawmill at Bridgewater. All the plant and equipment is sitting at Bridgewater waiting to go together. Unfortunately, the land that he purchased happened to be land on which it was proposed, although nobody knew it, to construct part of the national highway. Websters, a rural based company in Tasmania, did not know that. When they found out, that prolonged the period of time involved. He had an agreement with Forestry that he would meet certain time commitments. Forestry then opted out and said, `You didn't meet the commitments, therefore we don't want you.'

I read the other day in the paper that the Country Sawmillers Association seem to have come to some agreement with North Broken Hill, I have to say under threat. A couple of people from Country Sawmillers said, `North has really got the arm twisted up the back here. They don't want us to put in an application for a woodchip licence. If we do, we're likely to suffer the consequences.' The consequences that they would suffer are simply these: the price for their residue from sawmilling operations would be reduced or refused, because under the current rules in Tasmania, that is what North Broken Hill can do. Again, that is unacceptable. You cannot allow those practices to continue. We have an obligation to ensure that in issuing export woodchip licences we do not allow that to continue. Those are just a few examples.

I propose to seek leave to table photographs of logs that have continually been going to woodchip mills. In this case these logs are going to Boral's woodchip mill. I am quite happy to provide them to Senator Parer so that he can look at them. I will then seek leave to have those photographs tabled. I can remember seeing on the front page of the Australian newspaper last year 10 or 12 people who lost their jobs at the Coolah Tops sawmill in New South Wales. They were sitting on a pile of logs, the last logs that they had to cut. When you see those logs and think about those people who lost their jobs, you have to wonder what we are really doing in this industry.

As you can see from the examples that I have provided—and they are but a few—the proposed regulations do nothing to rectify these problems. I know the government will say that it is rubbish, but let us have a look at what is proposed. As I said before, under the pre-existing regulations at least two million tonnes, or around that, of wood for woodchips were sourced from sawmill residues. The proposed ceiling has been lifted by one million tonnes. But in reality, as I said earlier, there is no ceiling, simply because of the degraded forest licences and trial shipment licences. This is exacerbated by the very loose definitions that are proposed, especially in the area of wood sourcing.

Let us go to the proposed regulations in terms of the definitions and look at what residue woodchips are. They mean `control of woodchips derived from sawmill residues or silvicultural thinnings'. It says `or silvicultural thinnings'. It does not say one thing. It does not say `sawmill residues'. There is no definition in here of what sawmill residues actually are. They could be anything. At least under the old regulations that you disallowed there was a specific definition for sawmill residues—very specific.

Page 4 says that `silvicultural thinnings' means `waste material resulting from thinning of regrowth forest for the purpose of improving the production potential of the forest'. That can mean anything. Let us go to the issue of `regrowth-old growth'. I asked the minister's office to explain to me what was their interpretation of `old growth-regrowth'. They said, `It's in the national forest policy statement.' I had a look and said, `What about the age difference?' They said, `It has nothing to do with age.'

Let me tell you, Senator Parer, that in Tasmania regrowth forest is considered to be anything less than 150 years old. Then you take that and you think, `Hang on. Haven't we been running an argument about an 80-year rotation for the production of sawlogs?' None of this gels. None of it fits; none of it stacks up. We have an obligation in this place to do something about it.

Again, in terms of the process, silvicultural residues and sawmill residues are not defined. `Degraded forest' is basically being left up to the minister of the day to say, `Tom, Dick, Harry or Sue have the expertise to determine what a degraded forest is.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Natalie.

—Maybe Natalie, too. The minister will say, `They have the expertise to determine what a degraded forest is and we'll accept that.' That is just not acceptable. We have to have comprehensive guide lines and criteria so that they can be appropriately interpreted.

BREAK.PARA: We also have to understand that the world has a shortage of timber and we have a responsibility to maximise the use of it. More and more consumers are going to demand that. We know that there is a change in the view of consumers around the world. Therefore, we have an even greater obligation.

No-one in the debate thus far—particularly the two ministers responsible, Senator Hill and Senator Parer—has made any comment or provided any reasons as to why the definitions have been weakened and what benefits will be had from weakening the definitions. It certainly will not lead to increased downstream processing in this country.

Moreover, even if we in the interests of the industry voted for these regulations in good faith, there are other issues that demonstrate that the government is not genuine about real industry development, about having an industry that will focus on import replacement and the creation of jobs and wealth for Australians and Australia. I will give you one example of why I make that statement, and that is the removal of funding for unions and others to participate in an appropriate forum such as the Industry Council and in a way that would allow a genuine and open approach to industry development. If for no other reason, these regulations do not address any of the real issues confronting Australia's forest industry.
But of course it does not stop there. When we look at the issue of equity, when we grant woodchip licences—and I want to very quickly deal with this because—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are running out of time.

—I know, Senator Parer; I am running out of time. Maybe I will have to finish it on the adjournment. When you have a ceiling in place, you cannot in any way grant licences equitably. You cannot. I know from the past, when we were in government, that you cannot have nine million tonnes worth of applications and have a ceiling of either five million or six million tonnes and do it fairly. It does not work and it ultimately ends up that the big players at the top end of town get the benefits and the others do not. You cannot do it and you will not achieve downstream processing in that way.

BREAK.PARA: I put to the government: you ought to withdraw these regulations and amend them such that you give a proper focus to downstream processing in this country and that you ensure that there is greater equity for all of the participants in the industry. If you do not, then you will have achieved nothing other than what was achieved in the past. I have been critical of that. I hope the government will do that and I urge senators to vote against these regulations. I seek leave to table the photographs. (Time expired)
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, Senator Murphy, has raised some very serious questions indeed. I believe the government should look at those questions that Senator Murphy has raised and not just hide behind the fact that the management of the forest industry is essentially a state responsibility. The Commonwealth government has not shied away from using its powers under the constitution to influence states to perform better in a range of areas. I believe the government ought to do this now by using its powers under the constitution and in accordance with the Export Control Act. It may well be that ultimately the Export Control Act will need to be amended. I will come to that shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murphy has raised some very serious questions indeed. As I understand it, he is saying that there ought to be a true incentive for the industry to encourage downstream processing and that these regulations should focus on the source of material for woodchips. I concede that it does not do so. The regulations extend the definition of `residue woodchips'. As Senator Murphy indicated, the definition is broader than what was contained in the now disallowed regulations of the previous government. Under these regulations, residue woodchips mean `control of woodchips derived from sawmill residues or silvicultural thinnings'. Senator Murphy indicated it was estimated that 40 per cent of the export woodchips in 1996 were sourced to the residue woodchips from downstream processing units. I am convinced that the government should seriously look at this question so as to give true encouragement to downstream processing. Senator Murphy has raised this issue fairly and squarely.

The people of Tasmania have often been told of proposals for future investment in Tasmania, particularly in the regional areas, and nothing has come from them. He referred to press releases from the North Broken Hill Company and from Boral. Those companies should bear in mind that they do have a responsibility to Tasmania. They always say that they adhere to that responsibility but, in the area that Senator Murphy has referred to and in the specific statements that have been made by those two companies, they have failed in that responsibility. I hope that they hear what is being said here and that they do take it on board.

That is not to say that they are not reasonably large employers in Tasmania. North Broken Hill provides considerable employment, but it does so because it is privileged to be able to exploit the resources of the state. I know the company will say that there needs to be an extended definition of what are residue woodchips and that there needs to be an additional provision for degraded private forests. I think it could probably reasonably justify its view on that, if it is talking about the long‐term establishment of native forests for the purposes of ensuring a future resource, and I acknowledge that point. No doubt, that is one of the reasons that the government has specifically made provision for degraded private forests.

I certainly will be and I think the parliament should be very alert as to how those particular degraded private forests are determined. There are provisions under these regulations for that, but there should also be some sort of surveillance. I know the minister's office intends to do this, but from time to time the parliament should have reports as to how that is operating so that we can consider those reports and take policy decisions on them. Senator Murphy has made some very valid points. I agree with him that further focus should be made on the source of the woodchips, because that will influence, to some extent, the requirement for downstream processing.

Senator Brown, in moving his disallowance motion, did not do his cause good in that he seemed to indicate there was a lack of faith or goodwill on the part of those who were involved in developing these regulations. Senator Brown should just forget about calling everybody slashers and burners of forests. I have heard that. He even called me that. When my family heard it, they burst out laughing, knowing of my association with the bush. I would rather be there now than here. I spent last weekend in Canberra and went out to Namadgi National Park for seven hours on Saturday and another six hours on Sunday. I looked out of my office window just a while ago towards the Brindabellas and wished I was up in that neck of the woods today.

It is important for Senator Brown to realise the sensibilities and niceties of this place. You do not get anywhere by imputing bad will or a lack of goodwill. In my view, one ought to take it for granted that people do have goodwill. That is not only a piece of practical advice but the right and proper thing to do.

Senator Brown should realise that sometimes we meet in this place to get the place working properly. We do that in the leaders meeting. I was quite surprised to read a press release by Senator Brown revealing publicly what occurs at those private meetings of the leaders. Those meetings, by the way, are privileged meetings. I thought they were privileged. The leaders and the whips get together at those meetings to see that this place works properly.
In his media release of 26 September, Senator Brown said this:

At a recent Senate leaders meeting I said that a private member's bill coming from the House of Representatives should not queue jump over private senators' bills originating in the Senate. I am very concerned at moves by Senator Harradine to have Kevin Andrews' bill expedited up the priority order in the Senate. At the next Senate leaders meeting on 8 October I—
that is, Senator Brown—
will be insisting that the Andrews bill is placed below all private senators' bills already introduced.

To be quite frank, I cannot recall what I did at that meeting. I do not think it is terribly important. If we are going to change the rules around this place, I would be happy to know it. If those private meetings, to which people go in good faith to try and get this place running properly, are ones where we are able to go out and tell the world what happens there, that is fine. I am happy about that, provided that I am told the rules.

I have been here a fair while and I always thought that those were the rules, that we do meet on occasions in good faith to see things work out properly. I just take the opportunity of saying that you do not do the cause any good by reflecting on the integrity of people in this chamber, as I believe you did when you introduced this disallowance motion.

A number of things have been said here. Quite frankly, I have been very seriously considering supporting the disallowance motion. I was very impressed with the contributions. I was concerned particularly about the comments made by Senator Murphy. The government must have regard to what he has said because he knows the industry backwards. My problem is that, if I vote for the disallowance motion—I do not know whether it will be carried or whether it will not be—we go back to the 1986 regulations. Frankly, there were no ceilings under the 1986 regulations—none at all. From memory, even under the previous regulations there were no ceilings in the regulations themselves. What happens under those circumstances? The government could attempt to implement its policy under the 1986 regulations. I am correct, I think, in saying that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister put out a statement today saying he can and will.

—Thank you. I did not know that. You seem to get the minister's press releases before I do. Senator Murphy has confirmed that the minister has indicated that, if these regulations are disallowed, he will implement the government's policy under the old 1986 regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Those regulations have no ceiling. Senator Murphy has said, quite perceptively, that although there is a ceiling of 5.251 tonnes in the regulations we are discussing there is no ceiling for degraded private forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the trial shipment.
—That would not be much anyway.
—It could be interesting to see how the government actually grants those licences.

—Yes. We should bear in mind that it will be limited. It has been suggested by the government that another million tonnes would be involved. I reiterate that if we disallow the current regulations we will go back to regulations where there is no ceiling. That must be of concern to everybody because if there is no ceiling specifically mentioned in the regulations then what do we have?

SPEECH.PARA: The government may well try to implement its policy, including its ceiling under the old regulations, but it will be an administrative decision subject to appeal. For example, a person who has made an application for a licence may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. You could have a situation, and I suggest you probably would have a situation, where the government could have a ceiling of five million tonnes or so but export woodchips would go over that ceiling.

That is precisely what happened under the previous administration. There was no ceiling. There was a government policy for a ceiling, but there was no ceiling in the regulations so there were appeals to the AAT. The net result was that additional woodchips were exported.

I hope that the government and the companies have regard to what Senator Murphy has said. It may well be that some of these issues will have to be referred to a committee at some stage. It may well be that the government's implementation of the regulations will need to be referred to a committee. We want transparency. I know the government is hoping to have transparency as a result of these regulations. I am certainly willing to assist the government in its efforts even though that might mean that the matters are referred to a Senate references committee at some stage.

BREAK.PARA: It may well be that there is a need to amend the export control act to ensure that a reasonable percentage of woodchips are sourced from sawmills and other downstream processing plants as a means of encouraging downstream processing.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they did that now, there would be no need for a ceiling.
—I take the point. For the reasons I have previously mentioned, I cannot see my way clear to vote in support of the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Senator Harradine has just outlined his argument which really is tipped in the balance by the fact that these regulations, if disallowed, would leave no ceiling on export woodchipping. That is the salient point of his argument. By interjection Senator Murphy pointed out that if the right thing was done by the timber industry these ceilings would not matter. In the last 60 seconds of his contribution Senator Harradine showed the contradiction in his position. It is not consistent and it is internally contradictory. It begs the question of voting for regulations which head the forest industry in Australia in the wrong direction.

SPEECH.PARA: I compliment Senator Murphy on much of the contribution he has made, in particular the revelations about the way in which this industry is mismanaged by those at the very top. Both the Forestry Commission in Tasmania—and the same applies to forest authorities in other states—and the big woodchip companies have an inordinate power to sway the decisions on forests in their favour and against the interests of the small players who are the real job creators and who are essentially the downstream processors in this country. That is where the jobs in this industry ought to be.

The industry ought to be plantation based, and it ought to concentrate on downstream processing. But, instead of that, we have a situation where politicians and governments bow to the dictates and the power of these giant export woodchip companies. With the regulations that the government wants, we have in place toothless, parliamentary resolutions so that what happened before can happen in the future. If these regulations are not disallowed, the outcome will simply be that we will see a faster rate of destruction of Australia's grand and ancient native forests on the altar of profit of a few mega woodchip companies.

The reason the ceiling does not matter is that it is so high that we do not have an export woodchip capacity. There is no requirement from overseas to sop up the extraordinary amount of forest that is allowed to be cut down under these regulations in the name of a properly regulated industry. It is a sham, and these regulations are a sham.

Whichever way one looks at it, the outcome will be that we will have the fastest rate of cutting and destruction of Australia's heritage forests in all of history, and at a time when we have less of those forests left than ever before. If that is not irresponsibility over the management of our forest resource, I ask what is.

I referred yesterday to that forest resource. Let me look at the environmental side of it. Through the nod of the minister—and I do not mean the Minister for the Environment; I mean the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the minister in charge of logging—these regulations will enhance the capacity of the industry at a national level to continue to erode into the wild forests of New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania and, potentially, Queensland. Those areas include the habitats of nationally recognised and celebrated rare and endangered species such as the koala, the Leadbeater's possum, the long footed potoroo, the red tailed black cockatoo and the white goshawk.

We have forests of national estate value in several states which will face the chainsaws and the bulldozers under the direction of these regulations. In Tasmania, my home state, we have the Tarkine, the Great Western Tiers and the Picton, Huon and Weld valleys. These are forests which are recognised as being of World Heritage value but, sadly, they are outside the current World Heritage boundaries and will be targeted by the export woodchip companies as they broad deeper and deeper into these majestic, green domains.

On top of this, yesterday in Newcastle the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer—the minister responsible for so much of what happens in our forests—gave us a warning in relation to this. He said that, if the decision is that small forest reserves will come out of the current process—that is, where 10 or 15 per cent of a regional forest is set aside for protection—he is not going to abide by it. Where those forests are left standing, he is going to open the way for them to be dug up.

What the minister has made clear is that, as far as this government is concerned, no forest reserve will be put aside without first giving access to the mining industry. Senator Parer's solution, as he calls it, for Australia's forests was this:
We have therefore determined that Regional Forest Assessments must include at least broadscale assessments of mineral prospectivity.

Our objective is to ensure that any new forest reserves set up under the . . . process provide for management plans which do not unnecessarily exclude access for mineral prospect exploration and, subject to environmental procedures, mining.
So what is left of the forests—that is, what is not cut down—will be open to be dug up under the direction this government is taking.

Why is it that 80 per cent of Australians are opposed to the continued destruction of our forest heritage yet are so comprehensively ignored? The answer is the woodchip companies themselves and the extraordinary lobby they have in this place and in state parliaments around the country. They have such sheer power, a power which the patch in the pants conservation organisations cannot hope to meet.

The fact is that at least $3 million a year is spent by the logging companies on public relations—and that is tax deductible. A large fraction of that is subsidised by the taxpayers. Who could blame the Wilderness Society for turning up at the opening of the Streeton exhibition last week in New South Wales? North Pty Ltd, the biggest forest destroyer in Australia, is trying to put a thin gloss of green over its ugly, chainsaw reputation by funding an art exhibition. That, I submit, besmirched the name of a great Australian artist.

BREAK.PARA: Beyond that is the matter of political donations. Today Senator Murray released some figures about how these giant corporations put cheques into the coffers of political parties. For example, if you look at companies like Wesfarmers and Boral, something between $300,000 and $500,000 went from those corporations to the Liberal-National Party—and even Labor Party—coffers in a two-year period.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all public.

—Does that make it right? Does that mean that the coalition sitting opposite is not at all influenced by the fact that hundreds of thousands of dollars from these woodchip companies are going directly into their campaign coffers? If that is not the potential for wrong influence against the interests of the Australian people—that 80 per cent—and our forests, I ask: what is? Senator Murphy used the term `corrupt' in referring to some of the practices that go on in the forests. I submit that that is corrupt. If it is not, it is certainly the template upon which corruption can flourish.

BREAK.PARA: Beyond that we have to look at the self‐interests of politicians in a more direct sense. I reiterate that you cannot disconnect a direct interest of people who are voting on an issue like this from the interests of the companies themselves. The Boral company, as compared with last year, is applying next year for a 16 per cent increase in the rate at which it converts our forests into woodchips. That is in Tasmania. In New South Wales, it wants to expand, under these new regulations, from 403,000 tonnes to 730,000 tonnes. It is applying for an 81 per cent increase and it stands to get it under these regulations. In Western Australia, WA Chip and Pulp wants to go from 750,000 tonnes to 900,000 tonnes—a 20 per cent increase. These regulations are paving the way for increased conversion of forests to woodchips and increased, in commensurate amount, profits that those woodchip companies make.

There happen to be a number of senators who have shares in those companies. In leading up to that matter, Senator Vanstone referred, on 17 March 1994, to the senators' register of interests. She said that the register and disclosure alone were not enough to make a real impact on the potential for conflict of interest. She said:
We establish a false sense of security in the community that we do not have to worry about people's interests because they are disclosed.
She went on to give an account of her husband's sale of shares in a casino interest in the ACT which may have had some conflict because a casino was under consideration at the time. She said:

We sold the shares because I did not want to be in the position of anyone being able to say, `Look, even though you are not government, in opposition you can make a difference to these things, whether or not you agree, whether or not you create difficulty'. If a casino had gone through with our support and Federal Hotels had had the opportunity to run it, I would have been very uncomfortable.

Senator Vanstone also said something that I think is a very salient message to every senator, particularly to those seven senators opposite who were on the register of interests at the start of October as having shares in woodchip companies. She said:

If people have a responsible position, they should make sure that they do not have a conflict. I think people should get out of the conflict rather than simply declaring it. I think declaring it is going halfway.

I agree with Senator Vanstone—declaration itself is going halfway. When there is a conflict of interest, it is required that the senator or member of parliament involved go the full way. Declaration is not enough. Avoiding the conflict is what is required.
There is not time for a divestment of shares, although all senators have known this matter would be dealt with in the near future. What is required is an abstention from voting in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're joking.

—Senators opposite may laugh, but this is not Enid Blyton. This not Seven Get Into Trouble . I am referring to seven self‐invested senators of Australia. Every woodchip truck carries a premium for them. Every tree cut, every marsupial destroyed and every eagle's nest which falls is to profit them. They should not vote. Mr Howard's ethics demand that they abstain; or else they stain this Senate with their self-serving interest.

BREAK.PARA: If this disallowance motion fails because of their vote, a new pall of wrong‐doing will hang over the forests of Australia which are being converted into woodchips and which will ultimately end up on the rubbish dumps of the northern hemisphere through the policies of this government, aided, abetted and directed under these regulations.

I urge every senator to consider this disallowance motion anew. I appeal to those senators opposite who have shares in these woodchip companies to think again about the clear conflict which is involved in their voting for these regulations in the interests of woodchip companies, in the interests of their own profitability and monetary return. It is not the right thing to do. They should abstain. Having said that, I commend this disallowance motion to the Senate and appeal to senators to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Brown's motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. As a division is called for, the bells will be rung.

PARA.EMPHASIS: In division—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before putting the question, pursuant to order of the Senate No. 17 I disclose that the register of senators' interests shows that I have, amongst other shares, Amcor and Boral; and I will be voting in this division.
—I have an interest in this matter in that I own Wesfarmers shares. I declare my interest and I intend to vote.
—I avail myself of the same opportunity and declare that the register of interests will show that I have an interest in some Boral shares; and I intend to vote.
—I also declare an interest. I have some Boral shares. On behalf of my Tasmanian interests I am going to vote.

—As I said in my speech yesterday, I declare an interest in this matter. I hold a couple of hundred Wesfarmer Cooperative shares and a couple of hundred Wesfarmer Ltd shares, which is quite clear in the register of interests; and I intend to vote on behalf of Western Australia.
—During the debate on this motion I indicated my holding of various shares. I again put that on the record.
—I declare an interest. I hold some Boral shares, as has been known publicly for many years.
—As with Senator Short, it has been on the public record for quite a long time that I also have Boral shares. I might say that I am the only senator here voting against my own interests.

—Perhaps there will be another time to have a debate on this point but I do think it is worth making the point that since I have declared an interest I have not declared—in fact, I have done the opposite—that I have a conflict of interest. There does seem to be a misunderstanding. If you have some interests they are on the public record for everyone to see what your interests are. It would be a mistake to make an assumption that one therefore has a conflict of interest.
—As I understand it, it is a matter of a declaration of an interest.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was last being discussed I referred to the government's design to make the awards of this country unattractive to industry and employees by making the system weaker and reducing conditions for many employees. Those opposite want to replace that effective award system with a system of individual contracts that are to be called `Australian workplace agreements'. We are told that somehow this will empower employers and employees. I agree that it will give more power to employers. It will, however, severely disadvantage employees.

SPEECH.PARA: We should examine the government's proposition. Under their proposal, when a person applies for a job and the employer says during the interview, `I want you to sign this agreement', that person has no power in those circumstances; they are not even an employee. There can be no doubt that this will lead to job applicants signing agreements they do not like, just to get a job.

There is clearly no bargaining in this type of situation; there is no power for the employee. So much for empowering new starters, particularly the young who seek employment for the first time. There will be no power for new starters. Every time a person wants to change jobs—and there are many thousands of employees who do that each year—they may well be confronted with a demand, however couched, that they sign an Australian workplace agreement.

What about existing employees, those who are employed and have some form of contract of employment? What power will they have? Perhaps I should start with casual workers—and there are many in many industries. They have no guarantee of continuing employment. Some would say their contract of employment is by the day and that they start a new contract of employment every day when they start.

If an employer puts an Australian workplace agreement before a casual employee and says, `Sign', then they have a choice: they can sign, as the employer says—and probably continue to be called in for work—or they can refuse to sign and risk being dropped from the roster for someone who does. In my view, this is a form of coercion, a form of coercion that is impossible to deal with from a legal or a human point of view. These employees will have no bargaining power. Where is the empowerment of these employees that the government promises? There is a net loss to them in this bill. These employees will be as vulnerable as new starters.

I turn to employees already in ongoing contracts of employment. What power is there for them in this bill? They can refuse to sign an agreement and stay under the award. However, if the employer offers them a choice of the award or an agreement which contains matters in excess of the award which already apply to them while removing access to other award provisions, the employee will be faced with an unfair challenge and possibly threat. That is, if you do not sign the agreement, those matters which are in excess of the award may not continue to apply because you have not signed an agreement which contains them but drops other award conditions. That will mean in some situations that a gun will be held at the head of employees.

It is the type of circumstance that I have regularly heard of from employers and their representatives when the question of the proper application of an award is raised with the employer. A common response—and I am talking about an employer who has not been properly observing an award—is, `If we have to meet this part of the award we will take away these particular conditions that are not part of the award.' This is the reality of bargaining in the workplace, and this system offers no empowerment to employees.

Employers and employees can already reach binding agreements without any change to the law, and the minister has already conceded this. It will simply allow employers to pressure employees to give up those rights contained in awards. There is no empowerment here. Even if there is a bargaining process without this imbalance, then who will hold the whip hand? Given that the bill prohibits any employee revealing the content of their agreement, how can employees bargain with any sound research or knowledge on what is achievable, what has already been agreed, and what similar skilled and experienced employees have been able to persuade the employer that they are entitled to?

The employer in many circumstances will have this information, so I would call this bargaining by employees a form of blindfold bargaining, if any bargaining takes place at all. If this is what government senators opposite call empowerment, then I think they are deluded and out of touch with the reality of the workplace. I would not have thought they would be so naive as to have that view. However, the alternative is even less flattering.

As for employees' access to unions or other outside resources in the bargaining process, I believe it is likely that this will be even less accessible than it is now. I gave the Senate an example last Thursday night of employees being advised by the employers' industrial representative as to the detail of a proposed agreement. When a union sought to circulate a document which set out some simple advice for employees as to their rights, the employers' representative directed employees to tear them up and throw them in the bin. That is the real world in many workplaces. The employer has a powerful hold over employees, and it takes a very strong person to oppose the will of the employer. Some have the strength. Some can ignore the potential economic sanction of being unemployed. Most are not as strong, and most cannot afford to put their families' welfare in jeopardy.

There is another question to be posed, and that is: will Australian workplace agreements become the contract of employment for employees? The contract of employment lasts only as long as the Australian workplace agreement is in force. That is, the term, whether it be one year or two, will be the term of the employment. At the end of the Australian workplace agreement, the employee is no longer employed and is in the position of a job applicant. They will have the bargaining power only if they have a skill that is in short supply; otherwise they will have no power, no empowerment.

The other question which arises is whether this will effectively remove access for many to the unfair dismissal provisions that this bill contains. That is, at the end of their contract they will not be an employee and therefore not have access to seeking reinstatement of their employment because they cannot negotiate a fair bargain with their employer about ongoing conditions of employment. The government's chest beating about maintaining those provisions may well be hollow claims given this possibility.

This aspect of the Australian workplace agreements provision is about empowering employers. It is a disgraceful breach of the Prime Minister's commitment that no Australian would be worse off with regard to their wages and conditions. It is a recipe for disharmony and discontent. It will create bitter people in the work force and will do nothing for productivity.

I am a member of the Australian Liquor Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union. I have spent most of my life representing many part-time workers, most of whom are women. Most of these women have had the benefit of an award guaranteed minimum daily engagement. This bill would remove that right for those women under federal awards. They are not highly paid, and they depend on a certain number of hours each day to make going to work each day worth it.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the cleaners employed in this building by a contract cleaning company. The impact of this bill will be to remove from the part-time cleaners employed here their current entitlement to a minimum number of hours each day. This bill will create the circumstances for a possible loss of income for the lowest paid workers in this building. The government is effectively attacking these employers with this bill. Why? There is no clear and discernible rationale available in the parliamentary debate so far on this matter. Can it be anything to do with empowering employees? Clearly not. It is in fact the opposite. Clearly it will disadvantage those employees. It will take away rights that they have now for no discernible reason.

I want to touch briefly on the disamalgamation provisions of the bill and particularly on the comfort that this government may have drawn from correspondence and approaches it received from Mr Peter James on behalf of the Liquor and Hospitality Division of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union in support of the disamalgamation provisions of this bill.

Mr James advised me at a meeting of the transitional national executive of that organisation that he drew his authority to support that aspect of the bill from a meeting attended by about 93 members. I further draw the attention of the Senate and the government to the fact that Mr Justice Madgewick of the Federal Court ordered that the office held by Mr James—namely, of the secretary of that divisional branch—had not been properly filled, and ordered that a new election be called. A ballot of members has been conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission and counted. Mr James was not the successful candidate in that ballot, although he was a candidate.

I would submit to the Senate that this is testimony of the fact that members of that part of the organisation Mr James purported to represent as supporting this part of the bill have repudiated Mr James's position and action in supporting this aspect of the bill. The government can now draw no comfort from Mr James's representations on the matter.

This bill is a disaster for employees generally in the service industries. Parts of these industries are represented by the organisation of which I am a member. In the hospitality industry, an industry that is highly casualised, the wages paid to employees will fall in real terms as a result of this bill and conditions will be reduced. TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking this evening to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, I want to focus particularly on the impact this legislation will have on women. Comparing award rates of pay, women do comparatively well in relation to men but, on the other hand, comparing over-award payments, which are determined outside the system, women fare badly. The supplementary payments concept introduced since 1989, which has brought minimum award rates closer to over-award rates of pay, has been particularly important for women. However, over-award payments remain a problem for women.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Industrial Relations Commission through test cases has been crucial in achieving this result in terms of award relativities, especially the 1969 and 1972 equal pay cases. It is this strong award system which has given Australia a higher female-male wages ratio than comparable countries. The thrust of the government's proposed changes is to actually undermine this whole award system to a minimal wages floor and replace it with a system of individual agreements. This will, over time, destroy the achievements of the award system. This will have a particular impact on women. Before the election, the coalition promised:

The IRC will have a continuing role. Some employees and employers will continue to rely on awards . . . Accordingly, the IRC will continue to settle disputes and determine wages and conditions of employment. Awards will be updated as currently occurs.

Under a Howard Government you can not be worse off.
And:

BREAK.PARA: We will not force workers off awards.
And:

The government will do this by changes to the award system and the system of workplace agreements and by removing the commission's jurisdiction to make orders for equal remuneration for work of equal value in the over-award area.

The safety net that has been built up over time is a set of employment conditions contained in awards. Currently, the commission can update the safety net in each award to ensure it remains relevant and secure. The commission will arbitrate above the safety net in special cases, but the government is proposing to strip the commission of its ability to arbitrate above a basic minimum standard.

The government is intending to limit the issues which can be included in awards.
