The Inspector‐General of Intelligence and Security is a crucial position in the Australian intelligence community. It is the office through which accountability in our intelligence agencies is encouraged. The office is responsible for assisting the relevant minister in overseeing and reviewing the activities of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the Defence Signals Directorate, the Defence Intelligence Organisation and the Office of National Assessment.

The purpose of these reviews is to ensure that these agencies act legally and with propriety, comply with ministerial guidelines and directives and respect human rights. The Inspector‐General's office conducts these reviews by way of constant monitoring of the intelligence agencies and responding to complaints against the agencies directed by the Inspector-General.

I begin my comments with the observation that the office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security appears to be greatly under resourced; however, it manages on the most part to fulfil all its legal requirements and roles with relative efficiency and effectiveness. The two points highlighted by the report are: firstly, the lack of resources available to the Inspector-General; and, secondly, the Inspector-General's ability to deal with its basic requirements regardless of this.

The workload of the Inspector-General has increased steadily since 1986, with a small drop over the past two years. This workload increased considerably in 1994‐1995 due to the work of the commission of inquiry into ASIS.

To its credit the Inspector‐General's office managed to keep the average duration of the complaint process from increasing substantially. The only sharp increase occurred during 1994‐95 when also dealing with the aforementioned inquiry. As the Inspector‐General mentions in his report, efficient processing time has occurred with `only a very small office to help him'.
The report further highlights that the work of the agency is of a high standard. This is evident by a number of results:

firstly, in all cases, ministers have accepted the recommendations arising from reports completed during the years; and, secondly, with some minor exceptions, there continued to be broad acceptance of inquiry outcomes by both complainants and the organisation itself.

The report also illustrates the work the Inspector‐General plays in encouraging internal reviews by the various agencies. An example of this is in regard to investigations of complaints against ASIO and the findings. The significant finding was as follows:

The majority of complaints, upon investigation, are revealed to be unfounded. Nevertheless, some expose deficiencies in the manner in which the Organisation has dealt with particular matters and ASIO appears keen to learn from its experience to take corrective action, where this appears warranted.

Both the role of the Inspector‐General in highlighting problems in the process of ASIO investigations and ASIO's willingness to improve that process are reflective of the general thrust of the report.

This brings me to the role that the intelligence agencies have played themselves in operating under the spirit of the legislation. In nearly all cases, the report illustrates cases where the agencies have established internal review procedures aimed at increasing accountability and efficiency of the complaints handling process. Additionally, the agencies have cooperated with the reviews and investigations of the Inspector‐General. For this illustrated commitment to accountability and cooperation, the intelligence community should be congratulated.

One area that I feel the report fails to explain adequately is point 42, entitled `Extent to which there has been a change with the Agencies as a result of my Office's activities'. This section states:

A number of recommendations were made aimed at improving the internal procedures of the agencies in the course of the year, in some cases, as a result of inquiries I conducted, or in others when the Office responded to requests for assistance or advice from agencies. During the year, the agencies accepted all of the recommendations of suggestions emanating from the inquiries I concluded.

It is encouraging to hear that recommendations to improve internal procedures have been accepted. I believe information in relation to what those recommendations were and which agency they relate to would be useful knowledge for the Senate.

The most significant problem for the Inspector‐General's office is fulfilling its primary role—that is, to monitor the agencies under its jurisdiction. Due to the level of resources and staffing this has become secondary to reacting to complaints that are brought to the Inspector‐General's attention. This is highlighted in section 8 under the subheading `The Year in Review', where the report states:
The commission of inquiry into ASIS found that the Office has become too complaints orientated to the detriment of its self‐initiated monitoring activity.

This issue creates the problem of the Inspector‐General being unable to monitor and possibly prevent problems occurring. As a result, the Inspector‐General involved himself with the intelligence agencies at a predominantly complaints level. Therefore, while the Inspector‐General and the intelligence agencies are working well in areas of accountability, additional resources could further enhance this process by increasing the chances of prevention.

In conclusion, the Senate can be pleased with the work of both the Inspector-General and the intelligence agencies in their review processes and cooperation between the various agencies. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —The surveillance of intelligence agencies is always a major difficulty for a democratic society. It is one that we manage very successfully in this country. We manage it through two mediums: first, through the appointment of the Inspector‐General of Intelligence and Security, whose position was created in the mid‐1980s, with powers equivalent to a royal commissioner to inquire into all activities relating to the five intelligence agencies; and, secondly, at another level we do it through the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the way in which parliamentary committees have developed over the years. For example, the United Kingdom for years refused to acknowledge that there were any intelligence agencies operating at all in the United Kingdom, despite all the popular novels that have been written about them. In recent years they have set up the security intelligence committee, with oversight of all the intelligence agencies in the United Kingdom. Although they have only been operating for 18 months and the Australian parliamentary committee, which looks only at ASIO, has been operating for nearly 10 years, their ambit of operations is very much wider than what we have. I think it is a requirement in a democratic society that we move more and more to oversight. One of the essential parts of that oversight is the Inspector‐General's office.

One of the things about intelligence agencies is that they are very much a closed culture. People tend to join an agency or be recruited to it and stay in it for life. It is different from the rest of the public service. If they have complaints about promotion, conditions of service or even selection itself, they really do not have the avenues of appeal that other avenues of civilian employment have. So the Inspector‐General has an important part to play in that regard.

The previous speaker, Senator Bishop, said something about the Inspector‐General's office being under‐resourced. I do not think it is lavishly resourced but I think it is drawing a long bow to say, given the volume of work—21 complaints last year—that a staff of six, as it is at the moment, is over‐stretched. I would be very surprised if that were the view of the Inspector‐General himself. I think for the present workload and the activities they have, it is probably adequate.

Getting back to the need for oversight, the intelligence agencies in Australia are all restrained by the law of the land. The various legislative statutes that set them up are very strict in their restrictions on the organisations. The agencies do observe those restrictions very much to the letter of the law, both with their own internal audit procedures on confirmation of their activities and through the independence of the Inspector‐General's office. In no sense are they running around with an Ian Fleming or James Bond type attitude. They are all, in my experience, very responsible agencies.

Of the five of them, ONA, DSD and DIO are intelligence assessment organisations. DSD collects, by technical means, the intelligence which it uses for assessment. So basically they do not come into much contact with the community at large.

ASIS is the overseas intelligence gathering service. Again, it does not come into much contact with the Australian community, or no contact at all. So it is not surprising that, of the 21 cases listed this year, I think 20 of them relate to the activities of ASIO. That is because ASIO is looking after internal intelligence matters: politically motivated violence, espionage and activities of that nature. It does therefore come in contact with a large number of Australians through the year.

In the nature of things, there are those who feel they have been aggrieved. But, for the scale of its activities, to have only 20-odd complaints in 12 months and for the Inspector-General to find that the great majority of those complaints—probably something like 18 or 19—have no basis at all for further investigation is good testimony to the way the agency is conforming to the law and the spirit under which it was incorporated.

At the same time, I think the Inspector-General—both the incumbent and his predecessor—has done a very good job with respect to the legislation that sets them in their position. I look forward to their report next year. In conclusion, the whole of the Inspector-General's position costs only $637,000 a year and we get good value for it. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

On 18 August 1992 the then Attorney-General, Mr Michael Duffy, referred to the Australian Law Reform Commission for inquiry and report a large number of Acts administered by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services (as it then was). Madam President, as you would understand, perhaps more than most, for a fair, just and generous society to operate, it must operate within a context of the law. This is the annual report of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, as it is now styled, and which was formerly the Department of Industry, Science and Technology under the former government. This is the annual report for 1995‐96. The previous government, of course, was the incumbent government for most of the time that this report refers to. I had the privilege of being minister for that department during that time.

I just want to say a few words about the department. First of all, under the new arrangements—and I am not criticising them—the former secretary of the department, Mr Sandy Hollway, has been transferred and is now the secretary of DEETYA, the department that has replaced DEET. I just wish to record in the Senate my appreciation of the opportunity to work with Mr Hollway as a departmental secretary. He is a very fine secretary, and I am sure he will serve in his new role extremely well. I think he played an important role in leading this department, along with deputy secretaries Spasojevic, Trenberth and Bell.

This is a department of many fine officers. It is a good department and one that needs to be a strong advocate for industry policy in Canberra. I say that, Madam President, for the reason that last week you would have noticed that the Economist magazine's intelligence unit interviewed 55 chief executive officers of multinational corporations around the world as to the attractiveness of Australia as an investment destination.

Unfortunately for Australia, the 55 chief executive officers panned Australia as an attractive investment destination. They did so for a number of reasons, some of which are quite shallow. That is not a reason to criticise them, but it is perhaps a reason to make sure that we redouble our efforts so that we are able to convince them that they are wrong in that their reasons are obviously too shallow or too superficial.

One of their criticisms of Australia as an investment destination is that our industry policy is incoherent—to use their word—and I think they have a point. The budget this year cut out of the industry portfolio a number of programs which are quite central for Australia to have an active industry policy. Those programs related on the trade side to the strength of Austrade and its ability to be an international market intelligence agency for Australian business so that they have a periscope into foreign markets at minimal cost to them and they are able to take advantage of market opportunity. The export market development grants scheme was slashed, severe cuts were made to the research and development program and chops and changes were made to industry policies, including the abolition of a whole range of bounties and a reduction in support for industry.

BREAK.PARA: This springs from the erroneous idea that we apply business welfare in Australia, to use the term applied by some elements of the bureaucracy and picked up, unfortunately, by the new government. We do not. Business welfare is a superficial term used to discredit any real debate or serious discussion about industry policy.

What the government needs to do in the post‐protectionist era for industry policy in this nation is to ensure that, while we do not bring back protection, we nonetheless have enlightened policies that encourage Australian companies to become internationally competitive, to grow our export dollar, to take a bigger share of international markets and to make sure that our manufacturing area grows to world standards. We need to stop selling cheap commodities like non‐value added commodities like wheat, wool, iron ore and coal and buying back sophisticated manufactured goods; we need to start developing the capacity to manufacture those goods in Australia.

I think that this is a cheap shot: styling policies which are aimed at driving the economy in that direction as business welfare. They are all policies which have been refereed, reviewed and demonstrated to create more value than cost to the economy. In fact, as a budget item, they have been cut as outlays. But if you were to consider their impact on revenue, the net balance is that the programs that have been reduced play a budget positive or a budget neutral role. Without those programs, we have a lopsided approach to dealing with the current account deficit but, more importantly, we have removed support from Australian business in order to become exporters and to compete on the world stage. This means that the job opportunities they may offer are limited and that their prospects are reduced. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good man.
—He is. I agree, Senator Woodley. In the short time he has been in the job he has proved to be a quite outstanding Human Rights Commissioner. This is a report that should commend itself to everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: He says on page 10 of his report that compulsory retirement restricts equal employment opportunities on the basis of age and he recommends the repeal of compulsory retirement provisions in the Public Service Act 1922 and other federal legislation. In one case, four people who were pilots had reached the age of 60. Their employer wanted to dismiss them, not because they were not able to carry out their functions as pilots, but simply because of their age. That is a wrong approach.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the AFP conduct a covert drug-related operation called Operation Neon in 1985 1986.

(2) In Operation Neon, did a civilian volunteer take delivery of a shipment of heroin in Hong Kong at the Kangaroo Pub and Travel Club and deliver it to members of a drug cartel in Queensland, with the intention of identifying a major component of the illegal narcotic traffic operating in Australia at the time.
(3) (a) Were changes made to the conduct of Operation Neon which were not agreed to by the civilian volunteer; if so, were those changes made without the knowledge of the civilian volunteer; and
(b) Did the changes place the civilian volunteer in jeopardy.
(4) (a) Was Operation Neon terminated prematurely without realising its full potential;
(b) Did Operation Neon have the potential to result in numerous arrests of members of a drug cartel in Australia; and
(c) Were only two members of the drug cartel convicted, and a number of illegal aliens deported.
(5) Did the civilian volunteer in Operation Neon provide a great amount of additional information to the AFP, both in relation to Operation Neon and to other drug-related activities.
(6) (a) What arrangements were made to compensate the civilian volunteer and to ensure the future welfare and safety of the civilian volunteer and the civilian volunteer's family;
(b) Were those arrangements the same as the arrangements originally agreed with the civilian volunteer prior to the commencement of Operation Neon; and

(c) Does the Attorney-General consider those arrangements to be appropriate to the circumstances and reasonable compensation for the civilian volunteer for the personal losses incurred by the civilian volunteer at the time and subsequently.
(7) Were some of the AFP officers whose involvement was central to Operation Neon subsequently charged with serious offences against the AFP.
(8) (a) Did the National Crime Authority conduct any investigation into the AFP in Queensland in any way related to its conduct of Operation Neon;
(b) What was the result of those investigations; and
(c) Were those investigations terminated when a senior AFP officer was appointed to the NCA.
(9) Was private investigator Allan Nelson employed in any capacity by the AFP at any time.
(10) (a) Was one of the members of the drug cartel convicted as a result of Operation Neon, Philip Kwong Ying Chan;
(b) Was Philip Kwong Ying Chan imprisoned under that name, and did he serve a sentence at a prison at Wacol in Brisbane;
(c) Did Philip Kwong Ying Chan apply for immigrant status in Australia prior to Operation Neon;

(d) Is there now any record of Philip Kwong Ying Chan having entered this country or having been naturalised under that name; if not, how did Philip Kwong Ying Chan enter and live in Australia for a prolonged period of time;
(e) Was there a record, in the AFP computer records prior to Operation Neon, of a person known as Philip Kwong Ying Chan (aka Chan Pei Feng) and identified as having triad links.
(11) (a) Was Ringo Liu deported after Operation Neon;
(b) Was Ringo Liu an illegal alien at that time;
(c) Did Ringo Liu apply to the liquor licensing authority in Queensland for a liquor licence to conduct a licensed restaurant called `Harbour View' at Birkdale in Queensland;
(d) Was Ringo Liu scrutinised by the liquor licensing authority and granted a liquor licence; and
(e) Was Ringo Liu an illegal alien at the time when he was granted the liquor licence.
(12) Did the civilian volunteer in Operation Neon ask the Ombudsman in 1989 to investigate the conduct of Operation Neon; if so, what was the result of that investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am advised that the AFP conducted a drug-related investigation code-named Operation Neon in 1986.
(2) I can confirm that a civilian volunteer did assist the AFP in the investigation of a drug importation from Hong Kong.

(3) (a)&(b) It is a long standing policy of the AFP that information concerning police operational matters, including operational procedures, should not be disclosed. Successive Ministers with responsibility for the AFP have endorsed that policy and adopted the practice of not revealing such
information.

(b)&(c) Operation Neon resulted in the arrests of three individuals; two were subsequently convicted and sentenced to terms of 12 and 15 years imprisonment respectively. A third defendant died as a result of illness. Seven illegal aliens were detected and subsequently deported from Australia.
(6) (a)&(b) The AFP does not divulge information relating to witness protection, nor does it divulge details of its operational procedures.
(c) Yes.
(7) Yes, one officer was charged, in 1993, with a number of criminal offences, none of which related to the conduct of Operation Neon.
(9) I am advised that enquiries have not located any record of the employment of the person named.
(b) Yes.
(c) The AFP has been advised by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) that Mr Chan was an Australian citizen prior to Operation Neon.
(d) DIMA has also advised the AFP that Mr Chan arrived in Australia in 1975, was granted residency in 1981 and was naturalised in 1982.
(e) See answer to (3) above.
(b) DIMA has advised the AFP that providing a conclusive answer to this question would require the retrieval of archived files.

(c)&(d) The Queensland Liquor Licensing Board has advised the AFP that Mr Liu has never been granted a liquor licence. If he is connected with the licence of the Harbour View restaurant, it is not as a licensee or licence applicant.
e) See (b) above.

(12) I am advised that a complaint was made to the Ombudsman's Office by the civilian volunteer in 1988. However, given the requirements of Section 87 of the Complaints (AFP) Act 1981, the AFP has advised that it would be inappropriate to divulge the results of the investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1996 (Hansard Page 3340) Senator Bolkus asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it not a fact that the South Australian Attorney-General, Mr Griffin, has publicly stated:

If the Commonwealth retreats from its [legal aid] obligations to the people for whom it has traditionally been responsible, the State Government is unlikely to be in a position where it can step in and fund the shortfall.

I also note that similar comments have been made by nearly all of Australia's state and territory attorneys-general. What are the implications for Australia's justice and legal aid systems, given that the states are either unable or unwilling to make up the shortfall in legal aid funding caused by your government's already announced decision to limit its traditional areas of responsibility in legal aid funding.

PARA.TAB: The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that the South Australian Attorney-General has publicly stated that the State Government is unlikely to fund the shortfall in the Legal Services Commission's budget resulting from the Commonwealth's intention to direct its funding to matters which arise under Commonwealth law.

The Commonwealth will continue to fund legal aid for people in need who require legal assistance for matters arising under Commonwealth law. No reduction in overall legal aid funding will occur if the States and Territories recognise and honour their responsibilities to provide legal assistance for matters which arise under their laws—particularly crime.

Under the present arrangements, the Commonwealth provides more than half of the total Government funds provided to legal aid commissions. In recent years, legal aid for family and civil law matters has not been given the same priority by legal aid commissions as assistance for criminal law matters. The Government believes that a proper apportionment of responsibility for legal aid between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories will lead to a reduced requirement for Commonwealth funding.
The reduction in Commonwealth funding will remove what has been, in effect, a subsidy by the Commonwealth in funding matters arising under State and Territory laws.
